editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: This play, called the wits, as it was acted without offence, may be printed, not otherwise.
A comedy, presented at the private house in black friars, by his majesty's servants.
The author William D'avenant, servant to her majesty.
London, printed for Richard Meighen, next to the middle temple in Fleetstreet. 1636.

div.head: To the chiefly beloved of all that are ingenious, and noble, Endymion porter, of his majesty's bedchamber.
div.p: Though you covet not acknowledgements, receive what belongs to you by a double title: your goodness hath preserved life in the author; then rescued his work from a cruel faction; which nothing but the forces of your reason, and your reputation could subdue. If it become your pleasure now, as when it had the advantage of presentation on the stage, I shall be taught, to boast some merit in myself; but with this inference; you still (As in that doubtful day of my trial) endeavour to make show of so much justice, as may countenance the love you bear to

closer.signed: Your most obliged, and thankful humble servant, William Davenant.

div.head: To the reader of Mr. William D'avenant's play.
div.l: It hath been said of old, that plays are feasts,
Poets the cooks, and the spectators guests,
The actors waiters: from this simile,
Some have derived an unsafe liberty
To use their judgements as their tastes, which choose
Without control, this dish, and that refuse:
But wit allows not this large privilege,
Either you must confess, or feel it's edge;
Nor shall you make a currant inference
If you transfer your reason to your sense:
Things are distinct, and must the same appear
To every piercing eye, or well-tuned ear.
Though sweets with yours, sharps best with my taste meet,
Both must agree this meat's or sharp or sweet:
But if I sent a stench or a perfume,
Whilst you smell naught at all, I may presume
You have that sense imperfect: so you may
Affect a sad, merry, or humorous play,
If, though the kind distaste or please, the good
And bad, be by your judgement understood;
But if, as in this play, where with delight
I feast my Epicurean appetite
With relishes so curious, as dispense
The utmost pleasure to the ravished sense,
You should profess that you can nothing meet
That hits your taste, either with sharp or sweet,
But cry out, 'tis insipid; your bold tongue
May do it's master, not the author wrong;
For men of better palate will by it
Take the just elevation of your wit.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: Bless me you kinder stars! How are we thronged?
Alas! whom, hath our long sick-poet wronged,
That he should meet together in one day
A session and a faction at his play?
To judge, and to condemn: for't cannot be
Amongst so many here, all should agree.
Then 'tis to such vast expectation raised,
As it were to be wondered at, not praised:
And this, good faith sir poet (If I've read
Customs, or men) strikes you, and your muse dead!
Conceive now too, how much, how oft each ear
Hath surfeited in this our hemisphere,
With various, pure, eternal wit; and than
My fine young comic sir, you're killed again.
But above the mischief of these fears, a sort
Of cruel spies (We hear) intend a sport
Among themselves; our mirth must not at all
Tickle, or stir their lungs, but shake their gall.
So this joined with the rest, makes me again
To say, you and your lady muse within
Will have but a sad doom; and your trim brow
Which longed for wreaths, you must wear naked now;
'Less some resolve out of a courteous pride,
To like and praise what others shall deride:
So they've their humour too; and we in spite
Of our dull brains, will think each side i'th right.
Such is your pleasant judgements upon plays,
Like parallels that run straight, though several ways.

list.item: Palatine the elder, richly landed, and a wit.
Palatine the younger, a wit too, but lives on his exhibition in town.
Sir morglay thwack, a humorous rich old knight.
Sir tyrant thrift, guardian to the lady ample.
Meager, a soldier newly come from holland
Engine, steward to sir tyrant thrift.
The lady ample, an inheretrix, and ward to sir tyrant thrift.
Lucy, mistress to the younger Palatine.
Ginet, woman to the lady ample.

div.head: Act. 1. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter young palatine, Meager, Pert. young Palatine.
div.l: Welcome ashore meager! Give me thy hand!
'Tis a true one, and will no more forsake
A bond, or bill, than a good sword; a hand
That will shift for the body, till the laws
Provide for both.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: Old wine, and new clothes sir,
Make you wanton! D'ye not see pert, my comrade?

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Ambiguous Pert! hast thou danced to the drum too?
Could a taffeta scarf, a long ostrich whing,
A stiff iron doublet, and a brazeele pole
Tempt thee from cambric sheets, fine active thighs,
From caudles where the precious amber swims?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Faith, we have been to kill, we know not whom,
Nor why: led on to break a commandment,
With the consent of custom and the laws.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: Mine was a certain inclination sir
To do mischief, where good men of the jury,
And a dull congregation of grey beards
Might urge no tedious statute 'gainst my life!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Nothing but honour could seduce thee, Pert!
Honour! which is the hope of the youthful,
And the old soldier's wealth, a jealousy
To the noble, and mystery to the wise.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: It was sir, no geographical fancy
(Cause in our maps, I liked this region here
More than that country lying there) made me
Partial which to fight for.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: True, sage Pert.
What is't to thee whether one don Diego
a prince, or Hans van Holme, fritter seller
Of Bombell, do conquer that parapet,
Redout, or town, which thou ne'er sawest before?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Not a brass thimble to me! but honour! —

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Why right! else wherefore shouldst thou bleed for him,
Whose money, wine, nor wench, thou never hast used?
Or why destroy some poor root-eating soldier,
That never gave thee the lie, denied to pledge
Thy cockatrice's health, ne'er spit upon
Thy dog, jeered thy spur-leather, or returned
Thy toothpick ragged, which he borrowed whole?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Never to my knowledge!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: Comrade! 'tis time —

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: What, to unship your trunks at Billings gate?
Fierce Meager! why such haste? do not I know,
That a mouse yoked to a Peascod, may draw
With the frail cordage of one hair, your goods
About the world?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Why we have linen sir!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: As much sir as will fill a tinder box,
Or make a frog a shirt. I like not friends,
This quiet, 'More jest posture of your shoulders!
Why stir you not, as you were practising
To fence, or do you hide your cattle, lest
The skipper make you pay their passage over?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Know Palatine! Truth is a naked lady,
She will show all! Meager, and I have not —

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: The treasure of saint marks I believe sir,
Though you are as rich as cast serving-men,
Or bawds led thrice into captivity!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Thou hast a heart of the right stamp; I find
It is not comely in thine eyes, to see
Us sons of war walk by the pleasant vines
Of Gascoiny, as we believed the grapes
Forbidden fruit: sneak through a tavern with
Remorse, as we had read the Alcharon,
And made it our best faith.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: And abstain flesh,
As if our English beef were all reserved
For sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Pert
sp.l: Whilst Colon keeps more noise
Than mariners at plays, or apple-wives
That wrangle for a sieve!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: Contribute, come!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Stand there close on you lives! here in this house
Lives a rich old hen, whose young egg. (Though not
Of her own laying) I have in the embers!
She may prove a morsel for a discreet mouth,
If the kind fates have but the leisure to
Betray the old one.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Palatine.
No plots upon generation; we two
Have fasted so long, that we cannot think
Of begetting any thing, unless
Like cannibals, we might eat our own issue.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.p: I say close; shrink in your morions! go!

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.p: Why hidden thus? A soldier may appear.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Yes in a sutler's hut on the payday:
But do you know the silence of this house,
The gravity and awe? here dwells a lady,
That hath not seen a street, since good King Harry
Called her to a masque: she is more devout
Than a weaver of Banbury, that hopes
T'entice heaven (By singing) to make him lord
Of twenty looms. I never saw her yet:
And to arrive at my preferment first,
In your sweet company will (I take it)
Add but little to my hopes. Retire! go!

div.stage: They step aside, whilst he calls between the hangings

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: We shall obey, but do not tempt us now
With sweet meats for the nether palate! do not —

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: What Lucy! Luce! now is the old beldame
Misleading her to a cushion; where she
Must pray, and sigh, and fast, until her knees
Grow smaller than her knuckles. Lucy! Luce.
No hope! she is undone! she'll number o'er
As many orisons, as if she had
A bushel of beads to her rosary!
Lucy! my April love! my mistress speak! —

div.stage: Enter Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Palatine, for heaven's sake keep in your voice!
My cruel aunt will hear, and I am lost.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: What can she hear, when her old ears are stuffed
With as much warm wax, as will seal nine leases?
What a pox does she listening upon earth?
Is't not time for her t'affect privacy?
To creep into a close dark vault, there gossip.
With worms, and such small tame creatures, as heaven
Provided to accompany old people?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Still bettered unto worse! but that my heart
Consents not to disfigure thee, thou wouldst be torn
To pieces numberless as sand, or as
The doubts of guilt, or love, in cowards are!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: How now Luce! from what strange coast this storm! hah!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Thou dost outdrink the youth of Norway at
Their marriage feasts, outswear a puny gamester
When his first misfortune rages out quarrel,
One that rides post, and is stopped by a cart:
Thy walking hours are later in the night,
Than those which drawers, traitors, or constables
Themselves do keep; for watchmen know thee better
Than their lantern! and here's your surgeon's bill,
Your kind thrift (I thank you) hath sent it me
To pay, as if the poor exhibition
My aunt allows for aprons, would maintain
You in cerecloths. —Gives him a paper.

sp.speaker: Meger.
sp.l: Can the daughters of Brabant
Talk thus when younker-gheek leads 'em to a stove?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: I say (Meager) there is a small parcel
Of man, that rebels more than all the rest
Of his body, and I shall need (If I
Stay here) no elixir of beef to exalt
Nature, though I were leaner than a groat!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: This surgeon's a rogue (Luce) a fellow Luce
That hath no more care of a gentleman's
Credit, then of the lint, he hath twice used!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well sir, but what's that instrument he names?

sp.speaker: Young Pall
sp.l: He writes down here for a tool of injection
Luce, a small water engine which I bought
For my tailor's child to squirt at prentices!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I sir, he sins more against wit then heaven,
that knows not how t'excuse what he hath done!
I shall be old at twenty Palatine,
My grief to see thy manners, and thy mind
Hath wrought so much upon my heart!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: I'd as live keep our marriage supper
In a churchyard, and beget our children
In a coffin, as hear thee prophesy;
Luce, thou art drunk Luce; far gone in almond milk,
Kiss me! —

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Now I dissolve like an Eringo?

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.p: He's ploughing o'the Indies, good gold appear!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: I am a new man Luce; thou shalt find me
In a geneva-band, that was reduced
From an old alderman's cuff; no more hair left
Then will shackle a flea; this debauched vineyard,
I will reclaim to comely bow and arrows,
And shoot with haberdashers at Finsbury,
And be thought the grandchild of Adam-bell!
And more (My luce) hang at my velvet girdle,
A book wrapped in a green dimity bag,
And squire thy untoothed aunt to an exercise.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nothing but strict laws, and age will tame you.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.p: What money hast thou luce?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I there's your business.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: It is the business of the world: injuries grow.
To get it, justice sits for the same end;
Men are not wise without it; for it makes
Wisdom known; and to be a fool, and poor,
Is next t'old aches and bad fame; 'tis worse
Than to have six new creditors, they each
Twelve children, and not bread enough to make
The landlord a tossed, when he calls for ale
And rent. Think on that, and rob thy aunt's trunks
Ere she hath time to make an inventory.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: A cunning pioneer! he works to th'bottom.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Hast thou no taste of heaven? wert thou begotten
In a prison, and bred up in a galley?

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Luce! I speak like one that hath seen the book
Of fate: I'm loath (For thy sake) to mount a coach
With two wheels; whilst the damsels of the shop
cry out, a goodly straight chined gentleman!
He dies, for robbing an attorney's cloak-bag
Of copper-seals, foul nightcaps, together
With his wife's bracelet of mill-testers!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: There sir! —Flings him a purse.
'Tis gold! my pendants, carcanets, and rings,
My christning caudle-cup, and spoons
Are dissolved into that lump. Nay, take all!
And with it as much anger as would make
Thy mother write thee illegitimate!
See me no more! I will not stay to bless
My gift; lest I should teach my patience suffer
Till I convert it into sin. Exit.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Temptations will not thrive. This baggage sleeps
Cross legged, and the devil has no more power
O'er that charm, than dead men o'er their lewd heirs.
I must marry her, and spend my revenue
In cradles, pins, and soap! That's th'end of all
That scape a deep river, and a tall bough.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: Palatine! How much?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Honourable pall!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you must accept without gauging
Your corporal oaths, to repay in three days!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Not we (Pall) in three jubilees, fear not!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Nor shall you charge me with loud vehemence
(Thrice before company) to wait you in
My chamber such a night; for then, a certain
Drover of the South comes to pay you money!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: On our new faithes!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: On our allegiance pall!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Go then! — shift, and brush your skins well, d'ye hear!
Meet me at the new play; fair, and perfumed!
There are strange words hang on the lips of rumor!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Language of joy dear pall!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: This day is come
To town, the minion of the womb (My lads)
My elder brother, and he moves like some
Assyrian prince; his chariot's measure leagues
Witty, as youthful poets in their wine!
Bold as a centaur at a feast, and kind
as virgins that were never beguiled with love!
I seek him now, meet and triumph!
Meager, King pall! —Exeunt omnes.
Pert.

div.stage: Enter sir morglay Thwack, Eld. palatine, new and richly clothed, buttoning themselves.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: Sir morglay! come! the hours have wings, and you
Are grown too old, t'overtake them: the town
Looks ( methinks ) as it would invite the country
To a feast.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: At which sergeants and their yeomen
Must be no waiters (Palatine) lest some
O'the guests pretend business: how dost like me?

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: As one, old women shall no more avoid,
Than they can warm furs or muskadel!

sp.speaker: Thwack,
sp.l: Palatine! to have a volatile ache,
That removes oftener than the Tartars camp;
To have a stitch that fucks a man awry,
Till he show crooked as a chestnut bough,
Or stand in the deformed guard of a fencer;
To have these hid in flesh, that has lived sinful
Fifty long years; yet husband, so much strength
As could convey me hither, fourscore miles
On a design of wit, and glory may
Be registered for a strange Northern act.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: I cannot boast those noble maladies
As yet; but time (Dear knight) as I have heard,
May make man's knowledge bold upon himself.
We travel in the grand cause! These smooth rags,
These jewels too, that seem to smile ere they
Betray, are certain silly snares, in which
Your lady-wits, and their wise compeers-male
May chance be caught!

div.stage: Enter young palatine.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Your welcome (Noble brother)
Must be hereafter spoke, for I have lost
With glad haste to find you, much of my breath! —

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.p: Your joy becomes you it hath courtship in't!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Sir morglay Thwack! I did expect to see
The archer Cymbeline, or old King Lud
advance his falchion here again, ere you
'Mongst so much smoke, diseases, law, and noise!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: What your town gets by me, let 'em lay up
For their orphans, and record in their annals!
I come to borrow where I'll never lend,
And buy what I'll never pay for.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.p: Not your debts?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: No sir, though to a poor brownists widow!
Though she sigh all night, and have the next morning
Nothing to drink, but her own tears.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: Nor shalt thou lend money to a sick friend,
Though the sad worm lie mortgaged in his bed
For the hire of his sheets.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: These are resolves,
That give me newer wonder than your clothes;
Why in such shining trim, like men that come
From rifled tents, loaden with victory?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Yes brother, or like eager heirs new dipped
In ink, that sealed the day before in haste,
Lest parchment should grow dear. Know youth we come
To be the business of all eyes, to take
The wall of our st. George on his feast day!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Yes, and then embark at Dover, and do
The like to st. Dennis: all this (Young sir)
Without charge too; I mean, to us; we bring
A humorous odd philosophy to town
That says, pay nothing!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: Why, where have I lived?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Brother be calm, and edify! But first
Receive a principle, never hereafter
(From this warm breathing, till your last could sigh)
Will I disburse for you again; never!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Brother mine, if that be your argument,
I deny the major!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Resist principles?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Good faith, though you should send me more epistles
Than young factors in their first voyage write
Unto their short haired friends; than absent lovers
Pen near their marriage week, t'excuse the slow
Arrival of the licence, and the ring,
Not one clipped penny should depart my reach.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: This doctrine will not pass, how shall I live?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: As we intend to do, by our good wits!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: How, brother, how?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Truth is a pleasant knowledge;
Yet you shall have her cheap, sir morglay here,
(My kind disciple) and myself, have leased
Out all our rends and lands for pious uses!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: What, co-founders! give legacies ere death!
Palatine the pious, and stmorglay!
Your names will sound but ill ith' calendar.
How long must this fierce raging zeal continue?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Till we subsist here no more by our wit,
Then we'll renounce the town, and patiently
Vouchsafe to reassume our mother earth,
Lead on our ploughs into their rugged walks
Again, grope our young heifers in the flank,
And swagger in the wool, we shall borrow
From our own flocks.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: But ere we go, we may
From the vast treasure purchased by our wit,
Leave here some monument to speak our fame.
I have a strong mind to re-edify
The decays of fleet-ditch, from whence I hear
The roaring vestals late are fled, through heat
Of persecution.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: What a small star have I,
That never yet could light me to this way!
Live by our wits?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: So live, that usurers,
Shall call their moneys in, remove their bank
To ordinaries, spring-garden, and Hyde-park,
Whilst their glad sons are left seven for their chance,
At hazard, hundred, and all made at sent;
Three motley cocks o'th right Derby strain,
Together with a foal of Beggibrigge!

sp.speaker: Thwa.
sp.l: Sir, I will match my lord mayor's horse, make jockeys
Of his henchboys, and run 'em through Cheapside.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: What beauties girls of feature govern now
I'th town? 'tis long since we did traffic here,
In midnight whispers, when the dialect
Of love's loose wit, is frighted into signs,
And secret laughter stifled into smiles:
When nothing's loud but the old nurse's cough!
Who keeps the game up, hah! who misled now?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Not sir, that if we woo, we'll be at charge
For looks; or if we marry, make a jointure,
Entail land on women? entail a back,
And so much else of man, as nature did
Provide for the first wife.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: I could keep thee,
Thy future pride, thy surfeits, and thy lust,
(I mean, in such a garb as may become
A Christian gentleman) with the sole tithe
Of tribute, I shall now receive from ladies.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Your brother, and myself have sealed to covenants!
The female youth o'th town are his; but all
From forty to fourscore, mine own: a widow
(You'll say) is a wise, solemn, wary creature;
Though she hath lived to'th cunning of dispatch,
Closed up nine husband's eyes, and have the wealth
Of all their testaments, in one month sir,
I will waste her to her first wedding-smock,
Her single ring, bodkin, and velvet-muff.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Your rends exposed at home, for pious uses
Must expiate your behaviour here; tell me,
Is that the subtle plot you have on heaven?

sp.speaker: Thwack
sp.l: The worm of your worship's conscience would appear
As big as a conger, but a good eye
May chance to find it slender as a grig!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Amazement knows no ease, but in demands,
Pray tell me gentlemen, to all this vast
Designment (Which so strikes my ear) deduct
You naught from your revenue, naught that may
Like fuel, feed the flame of your expense?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Brother, not so much as will find a Jew
Bacon to his eggs: these gay tempting weeds,
These Eastern stones of cunning foil, bespoke
'Gainst our arrival here, together with
A certain stock of crowns in either's purse,
Is all the charge that from our proper own,
Begins or furthers the magnific plot,
And of these crowns, not one must be usurped
By you.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: No relief, but wit and good counsel!

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: The stock my father left you, if your care
Had purposed so discreet a course might well
have set you up i'th trade, but we spend light!
Our coach is yet unwheeled, sir morglay, come,
Let's suit those Friesland horse with our own strain!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.p: Why gentlemen, will the design keep horses?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: May be sir they shall live by their wits too!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Their masters are bad tutors else; well, how
You'll work the ladies, and weak gentry here
By your fine gilded pills, a faith that is
Not old may guess without distrust. But sirs,
The city (Take't on my experiment)
Will not be gulled!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Not gulled? they dare not be
So impudent! I say they shall be gulled,
And trust, and break, and pawn their charter too!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Is it lawful (Brother) for me to laugh
That have no money?

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.p: Yes sir, at yourself!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Two that have tasted nature's kindness arts,
And men, have shined in moving camps; have seen
Courts in their solemn business, and vain pride;
Conversed so long i'th town here, that you know
Each sign, and pebble in the streets; for you
(After a long retirement) to lease forth
Your wealthy pleasant lands, to feed John Crump,
The cripple, widow needy, and Abraham
Sloth, the beadsman of More-dale? Then (Forsooth)
Persuade yourselves to live here by your wits.

sp.speaker: Thwack
sp.l: Where we never cheated in our youth, we resolve
To cozen in our age.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: Brother, I came
To be your wise example in the arts
That lead to thriving glory, and supreme life;
Not through the humble ways wherein dull lords
Of lands, and sheep do walk; men that depend
On the fantastic winds on fleeting clouds,
On seasons more uncertain than themselves,
When they would hope or fear; but you are warm
In another's silk, and make your tame ease
Virtue, call it content, and quietness!

sp.speaker: Thwack
sp.l: Write letters to your brother! do! and be
Forsworn, in every long parenthesis,
For twenty pound sent you in butcher's silver!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Rebukes are precious! cast them not away!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Neither of these philosophers were born
To above five senses; why then should they
Have hope, to do things greater, and more new
I'th world, than I? This devil plenty thrusts
Strange boldness upon men! well, you may laugh
With so much violence, till it consume
Your breath! Though sullen want, the enemy
Of wit, have sunk her low; if pregnant wine
Can raise her up, this day she shall be mine. Exit.

div.head: Act. 2. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter the lady ample, engine, Ginet.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: My guardian horsed? this evening say'st thou engine?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: It's an hour (Madam) since he smelled the town?

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Sawest thou his slender empty leg in th'stirrup?
His ivory box on his smooth ebon staff
New civeted, and tied to's gouty wrist?
With his warped face close buttoned in his hood,
That men may take him for a monk disguised,
And fled post from a pursuivant!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: (Madam) beware I pray, lest th'age and cunning
He is master of, prepare you a revenge,
And such as your fine wit shall ne'er entreat
Your patience to digest. Tomorrow night
Th'extremest minute of your wardship is
Expired, and we magicians of the house
Believe this hasty journey he hath ta'en
Is to provide a husband for your sheets!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: And such a one, as judgement and nine eyes
Must needs dislike, that's composition may
Grow up to his own thrifty wish.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Madam.
Your arrow was well aimed; I call him master,
But I am servant unto truth, and you.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: He choose a husband, fit to guide, and sway
My beauty's wealthy dowry, and my heart?
I'll make election to delight myself:
What composition strictest laws will give;
His guardianship may take from the rich bank
my father left, and not devour my land.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: Your ladyship has lived six years beneath
His roof, therefore may guess the colour
Of his heart, and what his brains do weigh.
But engine (Madam) is your humble creature.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: I have bounty, engine!
And thou shalt largely taste it, when the next
Fair sun is set, for then my wardship ends —Knocking within.
That speaks command, or hast open the door.
Lucy! weeping my wench? melting thine eyes,
As they had trespassed against light, and thou
Wouldst give them darkness for a punishment.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Undone (Madam) without all hope, but what
Your pity will vouchsafe to minister!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Hast thou been struck by infamy? or comest
A mourner from the funeral of love?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: I am the mourner, and the mourned; dead to
Myself; but left not rich enough to buy a grave:
My cruel aunt hath banished me her roof,
Exposed me to the night, the winds, and what
The raging elements on wanderers lay,
Left naked, as first infancy or truth.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: I could ne'er endure that old moist eyed lady!
Methought she prayed too oft.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: A mere receipt
To make her long winded, which our devout
Physicians now prescribe to defer death.
But Lucy, can she urge no cause for this
Strange wrath, that you would willingly conceal!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Suspicions of my chastity; which heaven
Must needs resist as false; though she accused
Me even in dream, where thoughts commit by chance,
Not appetite.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What ground had her suspect?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Young Palatine (That wooed my heart until
He gathered fondness where he planted love)
Was fallen into such want, as eager blood,
And youth could not endure, and keep the laws
Inviolate. I to prevent my fear,
Sold all my jewels, and my trifling wealth
Bestowed them on him; and she thinks a more
unholy consequence attends the gift.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: This luce, is such apostasy in wit,
As nature must degrade herself in woman to
Forgive? shall love put thee to charge? couldst thou
Permit thy lover to become thy pensioner?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Her sense will now be tickled till it ache!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Thy feature and thy wit, are wealth enough
To keep thee high in all those vanities
That wild ambition, or expensive pride
Perform in youth; but thou invert'st their use
Thy lover like the foolish adamant,
The steel; thou fiercely dost allure, and draw,
To spend thy virtue, not to get by it.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: This doctrine (Madam) is but new to me.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: How have I lived thinkst thou? e'en by my wits!
My guardians contribution gave us gowns;
But cut from th'curtains of a carrier's bed:
Jewels we wore, but such as potter's wives
Bake in the furnace for their daughter's wrists!
My woman's smock's so course, as they were spun
O'th tackling of a ship.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: A coat of male
Quilted with wire, was soft sarsenet to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Our diet, scarce so much as is prescribed
To mortify; two eggs of emmets poached
A single bird no bigger than a bee,
Made up a feast.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: He had starved me, but that
The greensickness took away my stomach!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Thy disease (Ginet) made thee in love with mortar,
And tho' eatst him up two foot of an old wall!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: A privilege my master only gave
Unto her teeth, none else o'th house durst do't.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: When (Lucy) I perceived this straightened life,
Nature (My steward) I did call t'account,
And took from her exchequer so much wit
As has maintained me since. I led my fine
Trim bearded males in a small subtle string
Of my soft hair; made they to offer up,
And bow, and laughed at the idolatry.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.p: A jewel for a kiss, and that half ravished.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: I feel, I am inclined t'indeavour in
A calling (Madam) I'd be glad to live!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Know (Luce) this is no hospital for fools!
My bed is yours, but on condition Luce,
That you redeem the credit of your sex;
That you begin to tempt, and when the snare
Hath caught the fowl, you plume him till you get
More feathers than you lost to Palatine.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: I shall not waste my hours in winding silk,
Or shelling peascods with your ladyship!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Frosts on my heart! what? give unto a suitor!
Know? I would fain behold, that silly monarch,
(Bearded man!) that durst woo me with half
So impudent a hope!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Madam, you are
Not far from the possession of your wish,
There is no language heard, no business now
In town, but what proclaims th'arrival here
(This morn) of th'elder Palatine, brother
To him you named, and with him such an old
Imperial buskin knight as th'isle ne'er saw.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What's their design?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: They will immure themselves
With diamonds, with all refulgent stones,
That merit price: ask 'em who pays? why ladies!
They'll feast with rich provincial wines, who pays?
Ladies. They'll shine in various habit, like
Eternal bridegromes of the day, ask 'em
Who pays? Ladies. Lie with those ladies too,
And pay 'em but with issue-male, that shall
Inherit nothing but their wit, and do
The like to ladies, when they grow to age.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My ears received a taste of them before.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Engine, how shall we see them? bless me, engine,
With thy kind voice.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Though miracles are ceased,
This (Madam's) in the power of thought, and time.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: I would kiss thee engine, but for an odd
Nice humour in my lips; they blister at
Inferior breath! This ring, and all my hopes
Are thine; dear engine now project, and live!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.p: I'd lose my wedding to behold these dagonets!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: My guardian's out of town! let us triumph
Like Caesars, till tomorrow night! thou knowest
I'm then no more o'th family! I would
like a departing lamp) before I leave
You in the dark, spread in a glorious blaze!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Madam, command the keys, the house, and me.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Spoken like the bold Cophetua's son!
Let us contrive within to tempt they hither:
Follow my luce, restore thyself to fame! —Ex. Eng. Amp. Gin. young palatine beckons Lucy from between the hangings, as she is going.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Luce! Luce!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Death on my eyes! how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: I'm Luce, a kind of peremptory fly,
Shift houses still to follow the sunbeams!
I must needs play in the flames of thy beauty!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You've used me with a Christian care, have you not?

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Come I know all! I've been at thy aunt's house ▪
And there committed more disorder than
A storm in a ship, or a cannon bullet
Shot through a kitchen among shelves of pewter.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: This madness is not true I hope!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Yes faith.
Witness a shower of malmsey lees, dropped from
Thy ants own urinal, on this new Morion! —

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why you have seen her then?

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Yes, and she looks like the old slut of Babylon
Thou hast read of. I told her she must die.
And her beloved velvet-hood be fold
To some Dutch brewer of Ratcliffe, to make
His you frowe slippers.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Speak low! I am deprived
By thy rash wine of all atonement now,
Unto her after legacies or love!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: My luce! be magnified! I am all plot!
All stratagem! My brother is in town;
My lady Ample's fame hath caught him girl:
I'm told he means an instant visit hither.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What happiness from this?

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: As he departs
From hence, I've laid two instruments, meager
And pert, that shall encounter his long ears:
With tales less true than those of Troy, they shall
Endanger him maugre his active wits,
and mount thee little luce, that thou mayst reach
To dandle fate, to soothe them till they give
Us leave to make, or alter destinies!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You are too loud! whisper your plots within.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter engine, elder Palatine, thwack.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: You call, and govern gentlemen, as if
Your business were above your haste, but know
You where you are?

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: Sir tyrant thrift dwells here!
The lady ample is his ward; she is
Within, and we must see her; no excuses!
She is not old enough to be locked up
To say new perukes, or purge for rheum.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Tell her, that a young devout knight, made grey
By a charm (T'avoid temptation in others)
Would speak with her.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: I shall deliver you both,
These tigers hunt their prey with a strange nostril!
Come unsent for so aptly to our wish? —Exit.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: But this sir morglay will not do, in troth
You break our covenants.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Why hear me plead!

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: From forty to fourscore, the written law
Runs so; this lady's in her nonage yet,
And you to press into my company
Where visitations are decreed mine own,
Argues a heat that my rebukes must cool.

sp.speaker: Thwa.
sp.l: What should I do? wouldst have me keep my chamber
And mend dark lanterns; invent steel mattocks,
Or weigh gunpowder, solitude leads me
To nothing less than treason; I shall conspire
To dig, and blow up all rather than sit still.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: Follow your task! you see how early I
Have found this young inheretrix, go seek
The aged out; bones, unto bones! Like cards
Ill packed, shuffle yourselves together till
You each dislike the game!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: 'Tis the cause I
Come for; a withered midwife, or a nurse
Who draws her lips together, like an eye
That gives the cautionary wink, are those
I would find here; so they be rich, and fat! —

div.stage: Enter Ginet.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: My lady understands your haste, and she
Herself, consults now in affairs of haste,
But yet will hastily approach, to see
You gentlemen, and then in haste return!Exit.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: What's this the superscription of a packet?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Now does my blood wamble! you! Sucket eater!

div.stage: Offers to follow her, Palatine stays him.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: These covenants (Knight) will never be observed,
I'll sue the forfeiture, leave you so poor
Till for preferment you become an eunuch,
And sing a treble; in a chantry, knight.

div.stage: Enter ample, Lucy, Ginet, elder palatine, and Thwak. address to kiss them, and are thrust back.

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Stay gentlemen! good souls! they have seen (Lucy)
The country turtles bill, and think our lips
I'th town, and court, are worn for the same use.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Pray how do the ladies there? poor villagers
They churn still, keep their dairies, and lay up
For embroidered mantles, against the heirs birth!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.p: Who is begotten i'th Christmas holidays.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Yes surely, when the spirit of mince-pie
Reigns in the blood.

sp.speaker: Ampl
sp.l: What? penny gleek I hope's
In fashion yet, and the treacherous foot
Not wanting on the table frame to jog
The husband, lest he lose the noble that
Should pay the grocer's man, for spice and fruit!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: The good old butler shares too, with his lady
In the box, bating for candles that were burned
After the clock struck ten.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: He doth indeed,
Poor country madams they're in subjection still,
The beasts their husbands make 'em sit on three
Legged stools, like homely daughters of an hospital,
To knit socks for their cloven feet.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: And when these tyrant! Husbands too, grow old
(As they have still th'impudence to live long)
Good ladies they are fain to waste the sweet
And pleasant seasons of the day, in boiling
Jellies for them, and rolling little pills
of cambric lint to stuff their hollow teeth.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: And then the evenings (Warrant ye) they spend
With mother spectacle the curate's wife,
Who does inveigh 'gainst curling and died cheeks,
Heaves her devout impatient nose at oil
Of Jessamin, and thinks powder of Paris more
Profane than th'ashes of a Romish martyr.

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: And in the days of joy, and triumph sir,
Which come as seldom to them as new gowns
Then humble wretches, they do frisk and dance
In narrow parlours, to a single fiddle,
That squeaks forth tunes, like a departing pig.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Whilst the mad hinds, shake from their feet more dirt
Than did the cedar-rootes, that danced to Orpheus.

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Do they not pour their wine too, from an ewer,
Or small guilt cruce, like orange-water kept
To sprinkle holiday beards?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: And when a stranger comes, send seven miles post
By moonshine, for another pint?

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: All these indeed are heavy truths, but what
Do you (Th'exemplar madams of the town?)
Play away your youth, as our hasty gamesters
Their light gold, not with desire to lose it,
But in a fond mistake that it will fit
No other use?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: And then reserve your age
As superstitious sinners ill got wealth
Perhaps for'th church, perhaps for hospitals.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: If rich you come to court, there learn to be
At charge to teach your paraquitoes French,
And then allow them their interpreters,
Lest the sage fowl should lose their wisdom on
Such pages of the presence, and the guard
As have not passed the seas.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: But if you're poor,
Like wanton monkeys, chained from fruit,
You feed upon the itch of your own tails.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Rose-vinegar to wash that ruffians mouth!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: They come to live here by their wits, let them use 'em!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: They have so few, and those they spend so fast,
They will leave none remaining to maintain them.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: You shall maintain us; a community
the subtle have decreed of late: you shall
Endow us with your bodies, and your goods;
Yet use no manacles called dull matrimony
To oblige affection against wise nature,
Where it is lost (Perhaps) through a disparity
Of years, or justly through distaste of crimes.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: Most excellent resolves!

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: But if you'll needs marry,
Expect not a single purse for a jointure;
Not so much land as will allow a grasshopper
A salad!

sp.speaker: Thwac.
sp.l: I would no more doubt t'enjoy
You two in all variety of wishes,
(Were't not for certain covenants that I lately
Signed to in my drink) than I would fear usury
In a small poet, or a cast corporal.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: You would not!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: But look to your old widows!
There my title's good; see they be rich too;
Lest I shall leave their twins upon the parish,
To whom the deputy o'th ward will deny
Blue coats at Easter, loaves at funerals,
'Cause they were sons of an old country wit!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Why all for widow's sir, can nothing that
Is young affect your mouldy appetite?

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: No in sooth, damsels at your years are wont
To talk too much over their marmalade,
They can't fare well, but all the town must hear't!
Their love's so full of praises, and so loud,
A man may with less noise, lie with a drum!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: Think you so sir?

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Give me an old widow that commits sin
With the gravity of a corrupt judge,
Accepts of benefits i'th dark, and can
Conceal them from the light. —Ample takes elder pall: apart.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Pray sir allow me but your ear aside!
Though this rude clime i'th Clough, presume
In his desires more than his strength can justify,
You should have nobler kindness than to think
All ladies relish of an appetite,
Bad as the worst your evil chance hath found.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: All are alike to me: at least, I'll make
them so, with thin persuasions, and a short
Expense of time.

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Then I have cast away
My sight; my eyes have looked themselves into
A strong disease, but they shall bleed for it.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Troth lady mine, I find small remedy!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Why came you hither sir, she that shall sigh
Her easy spirits into wind for you,
Must not have hope the kindness of your breath
Will ere recover her.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: What do I hear? Hymen defend?
But three good corners to your little heart,
And two already broiling on love's altar?
Does this become her Ginet, speak?

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.p: As age, and half a smock would become me.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Thou'st caught her palatine; insinuate rogue? —

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Love him, you must recant, or the small God
And I shall quarrel, when we meet i'th clouds.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: 'Slight, see how she stands, speak to her.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Peace knight! it is apt cunning that we go;
Disdain is like to water poured on ice,
Quenches the flame a while to raise it higher.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Engine show them their way. —Enter engine.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: It lies here gentlemen! —

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: There needs small summons, we are gone! but d'ye hear,
We will receive no letters, we, though sent
By'th incorporeal spy your dwarf, or Audry
Of the chamber, that would deliver them
With as much caution, as they were attachments
Upon money newly paid.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Nor no message
From the old widow your mother (If you
Have one) no, though she send for me when she
Is giving up her testy ghost; and lies
Half drowned in rheum, those floods of rheum, in which
Her maids do daily dive to seek the teeth
She coughed out last. —Exeunt engine, Eld. Pall. Thwack.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Lass! good old gentleman!
We shall see him shortly in as many nightcaps,
As would make sick Mahomet a turban
For the winter.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Are they gone Luce?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Not like the hours, for they'll return again
Ere long ▪ oh you carried your false love rarely!

sp.speaker: Amp
sp.p: How impudent these country fellows are?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: He thinks you're caught; he has you between's teeth,
And intends you for the very next bit
He means to swallow.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Luce, I have a thousand thoughts
More than a kerchief can keep in: quick girl!
Let us consult, and thou shalt find what silly snipes
These witty gentlemen shall prove, and in
Their own confession too, or I'll cry flounders else,
And walk with my petticoat tucked up like
A long maid of Almaineny. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the: Palatine, Meager, pert, the two last being new clothed.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Don meager, and don pert, you neither found
These embroidered skins in your mother's womb:
Surely natures wardrobe is not thus laced!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: We flourish pall, by th'charter of thy smiles,
A little magnified, with show, and thought
Of our new plot.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: The chambers bravely hung!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: To thy own wish, a bed and canopy
Prepared all from our numbred pence; if it
Should fail, meager, and I, must creep into
Our quondam rags, a transmigration pall,
Which our divinity can ill endure.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: If I have more left t'maintain a large stomach,
And a long bladder, than one comely shilling,
Together with a single ounce of hope;
I am the son of a carman.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Do you suspect my prophecies,
That am your mint, your grand exchequer?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Pall, no suspicions pall, but we that embark
Our whole stock in one vessel, would be glad
To have all pirates ashore, and the winds
In a calm humour!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: How fares th'intelligence?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: I left they at the lady Ample's house
This street they needs must pass, if they reach home.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: O I would fain project 'gainst the old knight,
Can we not share him too?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: This wheel must move
Alone, sir morglay Thwack's too rugged yet,
he'd interrupt the course, a little more
O'th file, will smooth him fit to be screwed up;

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Shrink off pall, I hear 'em!

div.stage: Enter thwack, elder Palatine.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Thou'st not the art of patient leisure to
Attend the aptitude of things; wouldst thou
Run on like a rude bull, on every object that
Doth heat the blood? this cunning abstinence
Will make her passions grow more violent.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: But Palatine, I do not find I have
The cruelty, or grace, to let a lady
Starve for a warm morsel. —Pert and meager take the elder Palatine aside.

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.p: Now my fine Pert!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Sir, we have business for your ear; it may
Concern you much, therefore 'tis fit it be
Particular.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: From whom!

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.l: A young lady sir.
It is a secret will exact much care
And wisdom i'th delivery; you should
Dismiss that gentleman!

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: A young lady! good!
All the best stars i'th firmament are mine!
Our coach attends us knight i'th bottom of
The hither street, you must go home alone.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: I'll sooner kill a sergeant, choose my jury
In the city, and be hanged for a tavern bush!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Will't ruin all our destinies hath built?

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Come, what are those sly silkworms there that creep
So close into their wool, as they would spin
For none but their dear selves. I heard 'em name a lady!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: You heard them say then, she was young, and what
Our covenants are, remember!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Young, how young?
She left her wormseed, and her coral whistle
But a month since: do they mean so?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Morglay, our covenants is all I ask!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: May be she hath a mind to me, for there's
A reverend humour in the blood, which thou
Ne'er knewest; perhaps she would have boys begotten
Should be delivered with long beards, till thou
Arrive at my full growth, thou'lt yield the world
Naught above dwarf, or page.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.p: Our covenants still, I cry!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Faith, I'll stride my mule too morrow, and away
To'th homely village in the North!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Alas, these silly covenants (You know)
I sealed too in my drink, and certain fears
Lurk in a remote comer of my head,
That say the game will all be yours.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: But what success canst thou expect, since we've
Not yet enjoyed the city a full day?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: I say, let me have woman; be she young,
Or old, grandam or babe, I must have woman!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Carry but thy patience like a gentleman,
And let me singly manage this adventure,
It will too morrow cancel our old deeds,
And leave thee to subscribe to what thy free
Pleasure shall direct.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: We'll equally enjoy
Virgin, wife, and widow, the younger kerchief with
The aged hood.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: What I have said, if I had leisure now
I'd ratify with oaths of thy own choosing.

sp.speaker: Thwac.
sp.l: Go! propagate! fill the shops with thy notched
Issue, that when our money's spent, we may
Be trusted, break, and dozen in our own tribe.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Leave me to fortune!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: D'ye here palatine.
Perhaps this young lady has a mother! —

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: No more, good night! —Exit thwack.
I have obeyed you gentlemen, no ears
Are near us, but our own, what's your affair!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: We'll lead you to the lady's mansion sir,
'Tis hard by.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Hard by!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: So near, that if your lungs be good,
You may spit thither: that is the house!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: These appear gentlemen,
And of some rank! I will in! Exeunt Eld. Pall. Meager. Pert.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: So, so! the hook has caught him by the gills;
And it is fastened to a line will hold
You sir, though your wits were stronger than your purse!
Sir morglay Thwack's gone home; his lodging I
Have learned, and there are certain gins prepared,
In which his wary feet may chance to be
Ensnared; though he could wear his eyes upon his toes!
I must follow the game close! He is entered,
And ere this amazed, at the strange complexion
Of the house, but, 'twas the best our friendship
And our treasure could procure. Exit.

div.stage: Eld: Palatine, Meager, pert, with lights.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Gentlemen (If you please) lead me no further!
I have so little faith to believe this,
The mansion of a lady, that I think
'Tis rather the decays of hell; a sad
Retirement for the fiend, to sleep in when
He's sick with drinking sulphur.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Sir you shall see this upper room is hung!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: With cobwebs sir, and those so large, they may
Catch and ensnare dragons instead of flies.
Where sit a melancholy race of old
Norman spiders, that came in with conqueror.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: This chamber will refresh your eyes, when you
Have cause to enter it. —Leads him to look in between the hangings.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: A bed, and canopy!
There's show of entertainment there indeed;
There lovers may have place to celebrate
Their warm wishes, and not take cold: but gentlemen,
How comes the rest of this blind house so naked,
So ruinous, and deformed?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Pray sir sit down:
If you have seen ought strange, or fit for wonder,
It but declares the hasty shifts, to which
The poor distressed lady is exposed,
In pursuit of your love. She hath good fame,
Great dignity and wealth; and would be loath
To cheapen these by make-her dull family
Bold witnesses of her desires with you:
Therefore, t'avoid suspicion, to this place,
Sh'ath sent part of her neglected wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: And will ere time grows older by an hour,
Guild all this homely furniture at charge
Of her own eyes; her beams can do it sir!

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.p: My manners will not suffer me to doubt!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: We hope so too: besides though every one
That hath a heart of's own, may think his pleasure;
We should be loath, your thoughts should throw mistakes
on us; that are the humble ministers
Of your kind stars: for sure, though we look not
Like men that make plantation on some isle
That's uninhabited; yet you believe
We would teach sexes mingle, to increase men!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: Squires of the placket, we know you think us.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Excuse my courage gentlemen! good faith
I am not bold enough to think you so.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Nor will you yet be wooed to such mistake?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Not all the art, nor flattery you have
Can render you to my belief worse than
Myself: panders, and bawds, good gentlemen
I shall be angry, if you persuade me to
So vile a thought!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Sir you have cause!
And in good faith ▪ if you should think us such,
We would make bold to cut that slender throat.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: That very throat, through which the lusty grape,
And savoury morsel in the gamesters dish,
Steal down so leisurely, with kingly gust!

sp.speaker: Meag
sp.l: Sir it should open wide, as th'widest oyster
I'th Venetian lake!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Gentlemen, it should!
It is a throat I can so little hide
In such a cause, that I would whet your razor for't
On my own shoe.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Enough! you shall know all!
This lady hath a noble mind; but 'tis
So much o'ermastered by her blood, we fear
Nothing but death, or you can be her remedy!

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.p: And she is young?

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: O! as the April bud!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: 'Twere pity faith, she should be cast away!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: You have a soft, and blessed heart! and to
Prevent so sad a period of her sweet breath;
Ourselves, this house, the habit of this room,
The bed within, and your fair person we
Have all assembled in a trice.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Sure gentlemen,
In my opinion more could not be done,
Were she inheretrix of all the East!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: But sir the excellence of your pure fame,
Hath given us boldness to make suit, that if
you can reclaim her appetite with chaste
And wholesome homilies; such counsel as
Befits your known morality, you will
Be pleased to save her life, and not undo her honour?

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: We hope you will afford her medicine by
Your meek and holy lectures, rather than
From any manly exercise, for such
In troth sir you appear to our weak sight!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Brothers, and friends a style more distant now
Cannot be given: though you were in compass
Thick, as the asps, I must embrace you both —
You've hit the very centre, unto which
The toils and comforts of my studies tend!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Alas we drew our arrow but by aim!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Why gentlemen I have converted more
Than ever gold or Aretine misled:
I've disciples of all degrees in nature
From your little punk in purple, to your
Tall canvas girl, from your satin slipper
To your iron Patten, and your Norway shoe!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: And can you mollify the mother sir,
In a strong fit.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Sure gentlemen I can.
If books penned with a clean and wholesome spirit,
Have any might to edify; would they
Were here.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: A small library,
Which I am wont to make companion to
My idle hours: where some (I take it) are
A little consonant unto this theme.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Have they not names?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: A pill to purge phlebotomy! A balsamum
For the spiritual back! A lozenge against lust;
With divers others sir, which though not penned
By dull Platonic Greeks, or Memphian priests,
Yet have the blessed mark of separation
Of authors silenced, for wearing short hair.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: But sir, if this chaste means cannot restore
Her to her health and quiet peace; I hope
You will vouchsafe your lodging in yond bed,
And take a little pains —Points to the bed within.

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: Faith gentlemen, I was
not bred on Scythian rocks; tigers and wolves
I've heard of, but ne'er sucked their milk, and sure
Much would be done to save a lady's longing!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: 'Tis late sir. pray uncase! —They help to unclothe him.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Your boot, believe't, it is my exercise! —

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Well; 'tis your turn to labour now, and mine
Anon, for your dear sakes gentlemen, I profess —

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: My friend shall wait upon you to your sheets,
Whilst I go and conduct the lady hither:
Whom if your holy doctrine cannot well
Reclaim, pray hazard not her life; you have
A body sir!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: O! think me not cruel! Ex. mea. eld: Pal.

div.stage: Enter the: palatine.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Pall! come in pall!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Is he in bed?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Not yet,
But stripping in more haste, than an old snake
That hopes for a new skin!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: If we could laugh
In our coffin pert, this would be a jest
Long after death: he is so eager in
His witty hopes, that he suspects nothing.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: O all he swallows sir is melting conserve,
And soft Indian plum! Meager, what news? Enter meager.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: Laid! gently laid! he is all virgin sure,
From the crown of's head, to his very navel!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Where are his breeches? speak! his hatband too!
'Tis of grand price, the stones are roseal, and
Of the white rock!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: I hung 'em purposely
Aside, they're all within my reach: shall I in?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Soft! softly my false fiend! remember rogue;
You tread on glasses, eggs, and gouty toes! —

div.stage: Meager takes out his hat and breeches, the pockets and hatband rifled, they throw 'em in again.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: Hold pall! th'exchequer is thine own! we will
Divide, when thou art gracious and well pleased!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: All gold! the stalls of Lombardstreet poured into a purse.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: These dear pall, are thy brothers goodly herds!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Yes, and his proud flocks; but you see what they
Come to? A little room contains them all
At last; so, so, convey them in again!
Because he is my elder brother!
My mother's maidenhead, and a country wit,
he shall not be exposed to bare thighs, and a
Bald crown! what noise is that? —Knocking within, pert looks at door.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Death! there's old Snore
The constable! his wife, a regiment of halberds.
And mistress queasy too, the landlady
That owns this house.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: Belike they've heard, our friend
The bawd, fled hence last night; and now they come
To cease on mooveables for rent!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: The bed within, and th'hangings that we hired,
To furnish our design, are all condemned,
My brother too; they'll use him with as thin
Remorse, as an old gamester would an alderman's heir!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: No matter, our adventure's paid! follow
Pall! and I'll lead you a back way, where you
Shall climb o'er tiles, like cats when they make love.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Now I shall laugh at those, that heap up wealth
By lazy method, and slow rules of thrift;
I'm grown the child of wit, and can advance
Myself, by being votary to chance,Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 3. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Snore, mistress Snore, queasie, and watchmen.

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: Days of my breath, I have not seen the like!
What would you have my husband do? 'tis past
One by Boe, and the bell-man has gone twice!

sp.speaker: Queasie.
sp.l: Good master snore, you are the constable,
You may do it (As they say) be it right or wrong!
'Tis four years rent, come Childermas eve next!

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: You see neighbour queasy the doors are open;
Here's no goods, no bawd left; I'd see the bawd!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: I or the whores; my husband's the King's officer,
And still takes care I warrant ye of bawds,
And whores! Show him but a whore at this time
Of night (Good man) you bring a bed i' faith!

sp.speaker: Queasie.
sp.l: I pray mistress snore let him search the parish,
They are not gone far, I must have my rent;
I hope there are whores, and bawds in the parish!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: Search now? it is too late; a woman had
As good marry a cowlstaff as a constable;
if he must nothing but search and search, follow
His whores, and bawds all day, and never comfort
His wife at night: I prithee lamb let us to bed!

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: It must be late; for gossip Nock the nayleman
Had catechized his maids, and sung three catches,
And a song, ere we set forth!

sp.speaker: Queasie.
sp.l: Good mistress snore, forbear your husband but
Tonight ; and let the search go on!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: I will nor forbear; you might ha' let your house
To honest women, not to bawds! fie upon you!

sp.speaker: Queasie.
sp.l: Fie upon me! 'tis well known I'm the mother
Of children! Scurvy Fleake! 'tis not for naught
You boil eggs in your gruel, and your man Sampson
Owes my son in law, the surgeon, ten groats
For turpentine; which you have promised to pay
Out of his Christmas box.

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: I defy thee.
Remember thy first calling, thou setst up
With a peck of Damsens, and a new sieve;
When thou brok'st at Dowgate corner, 'cause the boys
Flung down thy ware!

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.p: Keep the peace wife! keep the peace!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: I will not peace; she took my silver thimble
To pawn, when I was a maid; I paid her
A penny a month use!

sp.speaker: Queasie.
sp.l: A maid? yes sure;
By that token, goody tongue the midwife,
Had a dozen napkins of your mother's best
Diaper, to keep silence; when she said
She left you at saint Peter's fair, where you
Longed for pig!

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: Neighbour queasy, this was not
In my time: what my wife hath done, since I
Was constable, and the King's officer,
I'll answer: therefore (I say) keep the peace!
And when we've searched the two back rooms, I'll to bed!
Peace wife! not a word! Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Eld. Palatine clothing himself in haste.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: 'Tis time to get on wings, and fly!
Here's a noise of thunder, wolves, women, drums,
All that's confused, and frights the ear! I heard
Them cry out bawds! the sweet young lady is
Surprised sure, by the nice slave her husband;
or some old frosty matron of near kin;
And the good gentlemen sh' employed to me
Are tortured, and called bawds! If I am ta'en,
I'll swear, I purposed her conversion. —

div.stage: Enter Snore, mist. Snore, queasie, and watchmen.

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: Here's a room hung, and a fair bed within,
I take it, there's the he bawd too.

sp.speaker: Queasie.
sp.l: Cease on the lewd thing!
I pray master snore, cease on the goods too!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: Who would not be a bawd? they've proper men
To their husbands; and she maintains him
Like any parish deputy.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: I am the constable,

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Good, the constable?
I begin to stroke my long ears, and find
I am an ass! such a dull ass, as deserves
Thistles for provander, and sawdust too
Instead of grains! O I am finely gulled.

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: Truly as proper a bawd, as a woman
Would desire to use?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Master Constable,
Though these your squires o'th blade and bill seem to
Be courteous gentlemen, and well taught, yet
I would know, why they embrace me?

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: You owe my neighbour (Mist. Queasy) four years rent.

sp.speaker: Queasie.
sp.l: Yes and for three bed ticks and a brass pot;
Which your wife promised me to pay this term,
For now (She said) sh' expects her country customers.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: My wife! have I been led to'th altar too;
By some doughty deacon, ta'en woman by
The pretty thumb, and given her a ring
With my dear self, for better, and for worse,
And all in a forgotten dream? But for whom
Do you take me?

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.p: For the he bawd.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Good faith, you may as soon,
Take me for a whale, which is something rare
You know, of this side the bridge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Snore.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed!
Yet our Paul was in the belly of one,
In my lord majors show; and husband you remember,
He beckoned you out of the fish's mouth,
And you gave him a Pepin, for the poor soul
Had like t'have choked, for very thirst.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: I saw it, and cried out
O'th city, 'cause they would not be at charge
To let the fish swim in a deeper sea!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: Indeed; why I was but a tiny girl then;
I pray how long have you been a bawd here?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Again! how the devil,
Am I changed, since my own glass rendered me
A gentleman: well, master constable,
Though every stall's your worship's wooden throne,
Here you are humble, and of foot; therefore,
I will put on my hat; pray reach it me! —Misses his diamond hatband.
Death! my hatband! A row of diamonds
Worth a thousand marks! Nay, it is time then
To doubt, and tremble to. My gold! my gold! —Searches his pockets.
And precious stones!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snore.
sp.l: Do you suspect my husband?
He hath no need of your stones, I praise heaven!

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: A plague upon your courteous midnight leaders!
Good silly saints, they are dividing now,
And ministering (No doubt) unto the poor!
This will decline the reputation of
My wit; till I be thought to have a less head
Than a justice of peace! if morglay hear't,
He'll think me dull, as a Dutch mariner!
No medicine now from thought? Good! 'tis designed!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: Come along! 'tis late.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Whither must I go?

sp.speaker: Queasie.
sp.p: To the compter sir, unless my rent be paid!

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.p: And for being a bawd!

sp.speaker: Elder Pallat.
sp.l: Confined in wainscot walls too,
Like a liquorish rat, for nibbling
Unlawfully upon forbidden cheese!
This to the other sauce, is aloes and myrrh!
But master Constable do you behold this ring?
It is worth all the bells in your church steeple,
Though your sexton, and sidemen hung there too,
To better the peal.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: Well, what's your request?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Marry, that you will let me go to fetch
The bawd, the very bawd, that owes this rent;
Who being brought, you shall restore my ring:
and believe me to be an arrant gentleman,
Such as in's scutcheon gives horns, hounds, and hawks,
Hunting nags, with tall e●ters in blue coats,
Sans number!

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.l: Pray let him go master snore;
We'll stay and keep the goods!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snor.
sp.l: Yes, let him husband.
For I would fain see a very be bawd!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Come neighbours, light him out! Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the: Palatine, ample, pert, Luce, Ginet, engine, with lights.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: A forest full of palms, thy lover (Luce)
Merits in garlands for his victory.
I'm wild with joy! why there was wit enough
In this design to bring a ship of fools
To shore again, and make them all good pilots!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Madam, this gentleman deserves to share
In your kind praise, he was a merry agent
In the whole plot, and would exalt himself
To your ladyship's service: if you please
For my humble sake, unto your lip too! —Pert salutes her.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Sir you are friend to Palatine,
And that entitles you unto much worth.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: The title will be bettered (Madam) when
I am become a servant to your beauty.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Why your confederate pert, is courtly too;
He will out-tongue a favourite of France!
But didst thou leave thy brother surfeiting
On lewd hopes?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: He believes all woman kind
Dressed, and ordained for th'mercy of his tooth!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: And now lies stretched in his smooth slippery sheets!

sp.speaker: Young Pall,
sp.l: O like, a wanton snake on camomile!
And rifled to so sad remains of wealth,
That if his resolution still disdain
Supplement from his lands, and he resolve
To live here by his wits; he will ere long
Betrothe himself to radish women for
Their roots; pledge children in their sucking bottles,
And in dark winter mornings, rob small schoolboys
Of their honey, and their bread.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Faith, meager and I, used him with as much
Remorse, as our occasions could allow:
'las, he must think we shreds of time
Have our occasions too!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: What (Madam) need he care?
For let him but prove kind unto his bulls,
Bring them their heifers when their crests are high;
Stroke his fair ewes, and pimp a little for
His rams; they straight will multiply; and then
The next great fair, prepares him fit again,
For'th city's view, and our surprise.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Why this young gentleman hath relish in't ▪
Yet when you understand the dark, and deep
Contrivements which myself, engine, and luce,
Have laid for this great witty villager,
To whom you bow as foremost of your blood ▪
You will degrade yourselves from all prerogatives,
Above our sex, and all those pretty marks
Of manhood (Your trim beards) sing oft with tapers,
As a just sacrifice to our supremacy!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: If sir tyrant thrift, your phlegmatic guardian
Leave but this mansion ours till the next sun,
We'll make your haughty brother tremble at
The name of woman, and blush behind a fan
Like a yawning bride, that hath foul teeth!

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis time you were a bed; for sure besides
The earnest invitation which I left,
Writ in his chamber, these afflictions will
Disturb his rest, and bring him early hither
To recover his sick hopes. —Enter meager.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Meager! What news? Madam, the homage of
Your lip again; a man of war believe't;
One that hath fasted in the face of's foe;
Seen Spinola entrenched; sometimes hath spread
His butter at the state's charge; sometimes too,
Fed on a salad that hath grown upon
The enemies own land; but pardon me,
Without or oil, or vinegar!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.p: Sir, men in choler may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.l: Your ladyship will excuse his new plenty;
It hath made him pleasant.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Meager! what news? how do our spies prosper?

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.l: Sir rare discoveries! I've traced your brother;
You shall hear more anon!

sp.speaker: Ginet ▪
sp.l: Your ladyship forgets how early your
Designs will waken you?

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.l: Madam, I'd fain be
Bold too, to hasten you unto your rest!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: 'Tis late (Indeed) the silence of the night
And sleep be with you gentlemen! Exeunt. Ample, Ginet: engine

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Madam, good night: but our heads never were
Ordained to so much trivial leisure as
To sleep: you may as soon entreat
A sexton sleep in's belfry when the plague reigns;
An aged sinner in a tempest, or
A jealous state's man when his prince is dying!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Pray dismiss your friends, I would speak with you.
Eig ▪ pall. Men o'the puissant pike, follow the lights. —Exeunt meager, Pert.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Pall, you are as good natured to me pall,
As the wife of a silenced minister,
Is to a monarchy, or to lewd gallants,
That have lost a nose!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: And why so dame Luce!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: So many yellow images at once
Assembled in your fist, and jewels too
Of goodly price, all this free booty got,
In lawful war, and I no tribute pall?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: What need it luce? A virgin may live cheap:
They're maintained with as small charge as a wren
With maggots, in a geese-monger's shop?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Well pall, and yet you know all my extremes?
How for a little taffeta to line
A mask, I'm fain to mollify my mercer
With a soft whisper, and a timorous blush;
To sigh unto my milliner for gloves;
That they may trust, and not complain unto my aunt;
Who is as jealous of me as their wives, and all
Through your demeanour pall; whose kindness I
Perceive, will raise me to such dignity,
That I must teach children in a dark cellar,
Or work coifs in a garret for cracked groats,
And broken meat!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Luce, I will give thee Luce, to buy

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What pall.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: An ounce of arsenic to mix in thy aunt's caudles,
this aunt, I must see cold, and grinning, luce,
Sealed t'her last wink, as if she closed her eyes
T'avoid the sight of feathers, coaches, and short cloaks!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: How many angels of your family
Are there in heaven? but few I fear, and how,
You'll be the first, that shall entitle them
To such high calling, is to me a doubt!

sp.speaker: Young Pallat.
sp.l: Why is there never a pew there (Luce) but for
Your coughing aunt, and you?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Hadst thou eyes like flaming beacons, crooked homes,
A tail three yards long, and thy feet cloven,
Thou couldst not be more a fiend, than thou art now;
But to advance thy sins with being hard,
And costive unto me!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: You lie Luce! you lie! —Flings her a purse.
There's gold! the fairies are thy mintmen girl,
Of this thou shalt have store enough, to make
The hungry academics mention thee,
In evening lectures, with applause, and prayer:
A foundress thou shalt be.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Of hospitals;
For your decayed self, meager, and pert,
Those wealthy usurers, your poor friends.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: A nunnery Luce, where all the female issue
Of our decayed nobility shall live
Thy pensioners: it will preserve them from
Such want, as makes them quarter arms with th'city,
And match with saucy haberdashers sons,
Whose fathers lived in allies, and dark lanes!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Good night pall! your gold I'll lay up, though but
T'incounter the next surgeon's bill; yet know
Our wits are ploughing too, and in a ground
That yields as fair a grain as this!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Farewell, and let me hear thy aunt is stuck
With more bay leaves and rosemary, than a
Westphalia gammon. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter elder palatine, and Thwack, dressing himself.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Quick, dispatch knight! thou art as tedious in
Thy dressing, as a court bribe; two ships might
Be rigged for the straits, in less space than thou
Carriest that same old hulk, can it be thought
that one so filled with hope and wise designs
Could be subdued with sleep, what dull, and drowsy?
Keep earlier hours than a roost hen in winter?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Palatine, the design grow all dream, magic,
And alchemy to me: I gave it lost!
Clove to my soft pillow, like a warm justice,
And slept there with less noise than a dead lawyer
In a monument.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: This is the house; dispatch, that I may knock.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: 'Slight stay, thou think'st I've the dexterity
Of a spaniel, that with a yaw, a scratch
On his left ear, and stretching his hind legs,
Is ready for all day: oh for the biscayan sleeve,
And Bulloigne hose, I wore when I was shrieve,
In eighty eight!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Faith thou art comely knight!
And I already see the town girls melt,
And thaw before thee.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: We must be content!
Thou knowest all men are bound to were their limbs
I'th same skin that nature bestows upon them;
Be it rough or be it smooth; for my part,
If she to whom you lead me now like not
The grain of mine, I will not flay myself,
T'humor the touch of her ladyships fingers!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Well I had thought t'have carried it with youth,
But when I came to greet her beauties with
The eyes of love and wonder, she despised me,
Rebuked those haughty squires, her servants that
Conveyed me thither in mistake, and cried,
She meant the more authentic gentleman,
The reverend monsieur, she!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: The reverend monsieur?
Why does she take me for a French Deane?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Her confessor at least, her secrets are
Thine own; but by what charms attained;
Let him determine that has read Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Charms? yes sir, if this be a charm — or this —Leaps and frisks.
Or here again t'advance th'activity
Of a poor old back!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: No ape, sir morglay,
After a year's obedience to the whip,
Is better qualified!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Limber, and sound sir!
Besides, I sing, little Musgrove; and then
