for, the Chevy chase, no lark comes near me!
If she be ta'en with these, why at her peril be't!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Come sir, dispatch! I'll knock, for here's the house ▪

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Stay, stay! this lane (Sure) has no great renown!
The house too, if the moon reveal't aright,
May for it's small magnificence be left
(For ought we know) out of the city map!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Therein consists the miracle, and when
The doors shall open, and thou behold, how lean
And ragged every room appears, till thou
Hast reached the sphere, where she (Illustrious) moves,
Thy wonder will be more perplexed; for know
This mansion is not hers, but a concealed
Retirement, which her wisdom safely chose
To hide her loose love.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Give me a baggage that has brains! but Palatine,
Did not I at first persuade thee, those two
Trim gentlemen, her squires, might happily
Mistake the person unto whom the message was
Disposed; and that myself was he?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Thou didst! and thou hast got (Knight) by this hand
I think, the mogul's niece; she cannot be
Of less descent; the height and strangeness of
Her port, denote her foreign, and of great blood!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: What should the mogul's niece do here?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Alas thy ears are buried in a woolsack;
Thou hearest no news! 'tis all the voice in court,
That she is sent hither in disguise, to learn
To play on the guitar, and make almond butter!
But whether this great lady that I bring
Thee too, be she; is yet not quite confirmed!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Thou talkest o'th high, and strange comportment that
Thou foundest her in!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Right sir! she sat on a rich Persian quilt,
Thridding a carkanet, of pure, round pearl,
Bigger than pigeons eggs!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Those I will sell!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Her maids with little rods of rosemary,
And stalks of lavender, were brushing ermines skins;

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: Furs for the winter! I'll line my breeches with them!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Her young smooth pages lay, round at her feet;
clothed like the sophy's sons; and all at dice;
The caster six wedges a cubit long
Cries one; another comes a tun of pistolets;
And then is covered with an argosy,
Laden with indigo, and cochineal !

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: This must be the great mogul's niece!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: As for her grooms, they all were planted on
Their knees, carousing their great ladies' health
In perfumed wines, and then straight qualified
Their wild, voluptuous heats with cool Cerbet,
The Turks own julip?

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Knock, Palatine!
Quick rogue! I cannot hold; little thought I
The thwacks of the North, should inoculate
With the moguls of the South! —Palatine knocks.

div.stage: Enter Snore.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Speak softly master Constable, I've brought
The very he bawd!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Blessing on your heart sir!
My watch are above at Trea trip, for a
Black pudding, and a pound of Suffolk cheese;
They'll ha'done straight: pray fetch him to me,
I'll call them down, and lead him to a by-room!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: Palatine, what's he?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: The lady's steward sir,
A sage philosopher, and a grave pandar!
One that hath writ bawdy sonnets in hebrew,
And those so well, that if the rabbins were
Alive, 'tis thought he would corrupt their wives.
Follow me knight! —

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Palatine,
Half the large treasure that I get is yours!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Good faith (My friend) when you are once possessed
Of all, 'tis as your conscience will vouchsafe.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Dost thou suspect? I'll stay here till thou fetch
A bible, and a cushion, and swear kneeling!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: My faith shall rather cozen me; walk in
With this philosopher — no words! for he's
A pythagorean and professes silence!
My ring master Constable —Snore gives him his ring, then exit with Thwack.
Here yet my reputation's safe! should he
Have heard of my mischance, and not accompanied
With this defeat upon himself, his mirth
And tyranny had been above humane sufferance!
Now for the lady ample, she (I guess)
Looks on me with strong fervent eyes; she's rich;
And could I work her into profit, 'twould
Procure my wit, immortal memory;
But to be gulled? and by such trifles too;
Dull, humble gentlemen that ne'er drunk wine,
But on some coronation day, when each
Conduit pisses claret at the town charge!
Well, though 'tis worse than steel or marble to
Digest; yet I have learned, one stop in a
Career, taint not a rider with disgrace;
But may procure him breath to win the race. Exit.

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter the: Palatine, engine, meager, pert, palatine richly clothed.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Your brother's in the house; the letter which
I sent to tempt him hither wrought above
The reach of our desires; my lady sir,
He does believe is sick to death; and all,
In languishment for his dear love.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Pert, and meager, though you have both good faces,
They must not be seen here; there is below,
A brother o'mine; whom (I take it) you
Have used not overtenderly.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: 'Slight he must needs remember us!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: We'll sooner stay t'outface a basilisk!
Whither shall we go?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: To snore the constable: morglay is still
A prisoner in his house; take order for's
Release, as I projected, but (D'ye hear)
He must not free him till I come.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Pall, will the dull ruler of the night (Pall)
Obey thy edict!

sp.speaker: Young Pall:
sp.l: His wife will, and she's his constable!
Name me but to her, and she does homage!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: Enough, we will attend thee there!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: This way gentlemen. Exeunt engine, pert, meager.

div.stage: Enter elder palatine.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: What's this, an apparition, a ghost embroidered?
Sure he has got the devil for his tailor.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Good morrow brother, morrow!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: You are in glory sir, I like this flourishing!
The lily too, looks handsome for a month;
But you (I hope) will last out the whole year!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: What flourishing? O sir, belike you mean
My clothes; they're rags, course homely rags, believe't;
Yet they will serve for'th winter sir, when I
Ride post in Sussex ways! —

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: This gaiety denotes
Some solitary treasure in the pocket,
And so you may become a lender too;
You know, I'm far from home!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: I'll lend nothing, but good counsel, and wit?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Why, sure, you have no factors sir, in Delft,
Leghorn, Aleppo, or'th venetian isles,
That by their traffic can advance you thus;
Nor do you trade i'th city by retail
In our small wares: all that you get by law,
Is but a doleful execution
After arrest; and for your power in court;
I know your stockings being on, you are
Admitted in the presence.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: What does this infer brother?
Men of design are chary of their minutes,
Be quick, and subtle!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: The inference is
You prosper by my documents; and what
You have achieved must be, by your good wits!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: If you had had a sibyl to your nurse,
You could not (Sir) have aimed nearer the truth.
I saw your ears and bags, were shut to all
Intents of bounty; therefore was enforced
Into this way; and 'twas at first somewhat
Against my conscience too!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: If not to vex
The zealous spirit in you, I would know why?

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Good faith I've searched records, and cannot find
That magna charta does allow a subject
To live by his wits; there is no statute for't!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Your common lawyer was no antiquary!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: And then (Credit me sir) the canons of
The church authorize no such thing.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: You have met with a dull civilian too!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Yet brother, these impediments cannot
Choke up my way; I must still on!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: And you believe the storeys of young heirs
Enforced to sign at midnight to appease
The sword man's wrath, may be outdone by you!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: I were unkind else, to my own good parts!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: And that your wit has power to tempt from the
Severe, grave bench, the aldermen themselves,
To rifle where you please, for scarves, feathers,
And for race nags!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: It is believed sir, in a trice!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: And that your wit can lead our reverend matrons,
And testy widows of fourscore, to scale
(And in their smocks) for frail commodities
To elevate your punk?

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: All this sir, is so easy,
My faith would swallow't, though t'had a sore throat!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Give me thy hand! This day I'll cut off the entail
Of all my lands, and disinherit thee!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Will you sir? I thank ye!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: But mark me brother; for there's justice in't,
Admits of no reproof; what should you do
With land, that have a portion in your brain,
Above all legacies or heritage?

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: I conceive you!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: O to live here, i'th fair metropolis
Of our great isle, a free inheritor
Of every modest, or voluptuous wish,
Thy young desires can breathe; and not obliged
To'th ploughman's toils, or lazy reapers sweat;
To make the world thy farm, and every man
Less witty than thyself, tenant for life;
These are the glories that proclaim a true
Philosophy, and soul, in him that climbs
To reach them with neglect of fame and life!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: He carries it bravely! As he had felt
Nothing that fits his own remorse; but know,
Sir eagle, th'higher that you fly, the less
You will appear to us, dim sighted fowl,
That flutter here below. Brother, farewell!
They say, the lady of this house, groans for
your love, the tame sick fool is rich; let not
Your pride beguile your profit! Exit.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: I suspect him! Not all the skill I have
In reason, or in nature can pronounce
Him free, from the defeat upon my gold,
And jewels! 'twas like a brother! but for
His two confederates; though I should meet
Them in a mist, darker than night, or Southern fens
Produce, my eyes would be so courteous sure,
To let me know them!

div.stage: Enter ample, carried in as sick in a couch, Luce, engine, Ginet.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Room! More air! if heavenly ministers
Have leisure to consider or assist
The best of ladies, let them show it now! —

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: How do you madam? O, I shall lose
The chief example of internal love
Of gentle grace, and feature, that the world
Did ever show, to dignify our sex!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Work on! I must stand sentinel beneath! Exit.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Is her disease grown up to such extremity?
Then it is time, I seem to suffer too;
Or else my hopes will prove sicker than she!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: More cruel than the panther on his prey!
Why speak you not? no comfort from your lips;
You sir that are the cause of this sad hour!

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: He stands as if his legs had taken root;
A very mandrake!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: How comes it (Lady) all these beauties that
But yesterday did seem to teach
The spring to flourish and rejoice, so soon
Are withered from our sight.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: It is in vain, t'inquire the reason of
That grief, whose remedy is past; had you
But felt so much remorse, or softness in
Your heart, as would have made you nobly just,
And pitiful; the mourners of this day
Had wanted then, their dead to weep upon!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Am I the cause? forbid it gentle heaven!
The virgins of our land, when this is told,
Will raze the monumental building, where
my buried flesh shall dwell, and throw my dust
Before the sportive winds, till I am blown
About in parcels less than eyesight can
Discern!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: She listens to you sir?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: If I am guilty of neglect;
Give me a taste of duty, name how far
I shall submit to love! the mind hath no
Disease above recovery, if we
Have courage to remove despair!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: O sir, the pride and scorns, with which you first
Did entertain my passions, and regard,
Have worn my easy heart away; my breast
Is emptier than mine eyes; that have distilled
Their balls to funeral dew! It is too late!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Ginet, my fears have in them too much prophecy,
I told thee she would ne'er recover!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: For my poor part, I wish no easier bed
At night, than the cold grave where she must lie!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Luce, Luce! entreat the gentleman to sit!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sit near her sir! You hear her voice grows weak!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: That you may see your scorns could not persuade
My love, to thoughts of danger or revenge;
The faint remainder of my breath, I'll waste
In legacies, and sir to you, you shall
Have all, the laws will suffer me to give!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Who, I? sweet saint, take heed of your last deeds!
Your bounty carries cunning murder in't;
I shall be killed with kindness, and depart
Weeping, like a fond infant, whom the nurse
Would soothe, too early to his bed!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Nay sir, no remedy, you must have all:
Though you procured her death; the world shall not
Report; she died beholding to you!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.p: Go to her sir, she'd speak with you again!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Sir, if mine eyes, in all their health and glory,
Had not the power to warm you into love,
Where are my hopes, now they are dim, and have
Almost forgotten the benefit of light!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Not love! Lady! Queen of my heart! what oaths
Or execrations can persuade your faith
from such a cruel jealousy!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: I'd have some testimony sir; if but
T'assure the world, my love, and bounty at
My death, were both conferred on one, that showed
So much requital, as declares he was
Of gentle humane race!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: What shall I do?
Prescribe me dangers now, horrid as those
Which midnight fires beget, in cities overgrown;
Or winter storms produce at sea, and try
How far my love will make me venture to
Augment th'esteem of yours!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: That trial of your love which I request
Implies no danger sir; 'tis not in me
T'urge any thing, but what your own desires
Would choose!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Name it! like eager mastiffs, chained
From the encounter of their game, my hot
Fierce appetite diminisheth my strength!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: 'Tis only this: for fear some other should
Enjoy you when I'm cold, in my last sleep;
I would entreat you to sit hear, grow sick,
Languish, and die with me!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: How! die with you! Takes Luce aside.
'Twere fit, you hastened her to write down all
She can bestow, and in some form of law:
I fear, she's mad! her senses are so lost,
She'll never find them to her use again!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I pray sir why?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Did you not hear what a fantastic suit
She makes, that I would sit and die with her?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Does this request seem strange? you will do little
For a lady, that deny to bring her
Onward her last journey; or is't your thrift?
Alas you know, souls travel without charge!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Her little skull is tainted too!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: Is he not willing luce?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: My best dear lady, I am willing to
Resign myself to any thing but death!
Do not suspect my kindness now; in troth
I've business upon earth will hold me here
At least a score or two of years; but when
that's done; I am content to follow you!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: If this persuasion cannot reach at your
Consent; yet let me witness so much love
In you, as may enforce you languish, and
Decay, for my departure from your sight.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Can you do less than languish for her death?
Sit down here, and begin! true sorrow sir,
If you have any in your breast will quickly
Bring you low enough!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Alas good ladies! do you think my languishment
And grief is to begin upon me now?
Heaven knows how I have pined, and groaned, since first
Your letter gave me knowledge of the cause!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: It is not seen sir in your face!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: My face! I grant you; I bate inwardly!
I'm scorched, and dried, with sighing to a mummy:
My heart, and liver are not big enough
To choke a daw! A lamb laid on the altar for
A sacrifice hath much more entrails in't!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yet still, your sorrow alters not your face?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Why no, I say! No man, that ever was
Of nature's making hath a face moulded
With less help for hypocrisy than mine!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.p: Great pity sir!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Though I endured the diet and the flux;
Lay seven days buried up to'th lips like a
Deceased sad indian in warm sand; whilst his
Afflicted female wipes his salt foam off
With her own hair, feeds him with buds of guacum
For his salad; and pulp of salsa for
His bread; I say, all this endured, would not
Concern my face! Nothing can decline that!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yet you are used sir, to bate inwardly!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: More than heirs unlanded, or unjointed wives.

div.stage: Enter engine.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: What shall we do? Sir tyrant Thrift's come home!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Sir tyrant thrift!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My lady's guardian sir!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: He meets th'expected hour, just to my wish!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What, hath he brought a husband for my lady?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: There is a certain one legged gentleman,
whose better half of limbs is wood; for whom
Kind nature did provide no hands, to prevent
Stealing; and to augment his gracefulness,
He's crooked as a witch's been!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Is he so much wood?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: So much, that if my lady were in health,
And married to him, as her guardian did
Propose, we should have an excellent generation
Of bedstaves.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: When does he come?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Tonight if his slow litter will consent;
For they convey him tenderly, lest his
Sharp bones should grate together: sir Palatine,
I wish you could escape my master's sight!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Is he coming hither?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: He's at the door! My lady's sickness was
No sooner told him, but he straight projects
To proffer her a will of his own making!
He means sir to be heir of all: if he
Should see you here, he would suspect my loyalty,
And doubt you for some cunning instrument,
That means to interrupt his covetous hopes!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Then I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: No sir, he needs must meet you in
Your passage down! besides, it is not fit
For you, and your great hopes, with my dependency
On both, to have you absent when my lady dies;
I know you must have all: sir I could wish
That we might hide you here! —
Draw out the chest within, that's big enough
To hold you: it were dangerous to have
My lady's guardian to find you sir! —They draw in a chest.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: How! laid up like a brushed gown, under lock
And key! By this good light, not I!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O sir, if but to save the honour of
Your mistress fame, what will he think to see
So comely, and so straight a gentleman
Converse here with a lady in her chamber!
And in a time that makes for his suspicion too,
When he's from home!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: I hate enclosure, I;
It is the humour of a distressed rat!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: It is retirement sir, and you'll come forth
again, so sage!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: Sir Palatine! —

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Your lady calls sir, to her, and be kind!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Will you permit the last of all my hours
Should be defiled with infamy, proclaimed
By lewder tongues, to be unchaste e'en at
My death? what will my guardian guess to find
You here?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: No more, I'll in! but think on't gentle lady!
First to bate inwardly , and then to have
My outward person shut thus and enclosed
From day light, and your company; I say
But think, if't be not worse than death! —He enters the chest.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Lock him up Luce, safe as thy maidenhead! —

div.stage: Enter sir tyrant thrift.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Engine, where's my charge engine, my dear charge?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Sick as I told you sir, and lost to all
The hope, that earthly medicine can procure!
Her physicians have taken their last fees,
And then went hence shaking their empty heads,
As they had left less brain than hope!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Alas poor charge! come, let me see her engine!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: At distance sir, I pray, for I have heard
Your breath is somewhat sour, with overfasting sir,
On holiday eves!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Ha! what is she engine?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: A pure, good soul, one that your ward desired
For love and kindred's sake, t'have near her at
Her death; she'll outwatch a long rush candle,
And reads to her all night the posy of
Spiritual flowers!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Does she not gape for legacies?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Fie no! there's a Cornelian ring, perhaps
She aims at, cost ten groats; or a wrought smock,
My lady made now 'gainst her wedding sir;
Trifles which maids desire to weep upon
With funeral tales, after a midnight posset.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Thou saidst below, she hath made me her heir.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Of all, e'en to her slippers and her pins!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Luce, methought Luce, I heard my Guardeans voice!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: It seems her senses are grown warm again;
Your presence will recover her!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Will it recover her, then I'll be gone!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: No sir, she'll straight grow cold again! On! on!
She looks that you would speak to her.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: Alas poor charge! I little thought to see
This doleful day.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: We all are mortal sir!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: I've taken care, and labour, to provide
A husband for thee; he's in's litter now,
Hastening to town; a fine young gentleman!
Only a little rumpled in the womb,
With falls his mother took, after his making.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Death is my husband now! but yet I thank
You for your tender pains, and wish you would
Continue it in quiet governing my legacies,
When I am passed the power to see it sir;
You shall enjoy all!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: This will occasion more church building;
And raising of new hospitals; there were
Enough before; but charge you'll have it so.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I'll make sir one request; which I have hope,
You'll grant in thankfulness to all my bounty!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: O dear charge! any thing! Your cousin here
Shall witness the consent and act,

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Because I would not have my vanities
Remain, as fond examples to persuade
An imitation in those ladies that
Succeed my youthful pride i'th town: my plumes,
Fantastic flowers, and chains: my haughty rich
Embroideries: my gawdy gowns, and wanton jewels,
I have locked within a chest!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: There sir, there the chest stands.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: And I desire it may be buried with me!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Engine, take care engine, to see it done!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Now sir, I beseech you leave me: for 'twill
But make my death more sorrowful, thus to
Continue my converse with one, I so
Much love, and must forsake at last.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Alack, alack! bury her tonight engine!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Not sir, unless she dies. Her ancestors
Have sojourned long here in st. Bartholomew's,
And there's a vault i'th parish church, kept only
For her family; she must be buried there.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: I engine, ay, and let me see; the church
thou knowest, joins to my house, a good prevention
From a large walk; 'twill save the charge of torchlight.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: What funeral guests? the neighbour's sir, will look
To be invited!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: No more than will suffice
To carry down the corpse; and thou knowest engine,
She is no great weight.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: And what to entertain them sir?

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: A little rosemary, which thou mayst steal
From th'temple garden; and as many comfits
As might serve to christen a watchman's bastard:
'Twill be enough!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: This will not do! Your citizen
Is a most fierce devourer sir of plums!
Six will destroy as many as can make
A banquet for an army!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: I'll have no more, engine.
I'll have no more! nor (D'ye hear) no burned wine;
I do not like this drinking healths to'th memory
O'th dead; it is profane.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: You are obeyed!
But sir, let me advise you now to trust
The care, and benefit of all your fate
Presents you in this house, to my discretion;
And get you instantly to horse again.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Why engine, speak?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: In brief, you know, that all
The writings which concern your wards estate,
Lie at her lawyers, fifteen miles from hence!
Your credit, he not knowing (Sir) she's sick,
Will easily tempt them to your own possession:
Which, once enjoyed, you're free from all litigious suits
His envy might incense her kindred to!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Enough engine, I am gone!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: If you should meet the crooked lover in
His litter sir (As 'tis in your own road)
You may persuade him move like a crab, backward;
For here's no mixture, but with worms.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: 'Tis well thought on engine! farewell engine!
Be faithful, and be rich! —

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: My breeding and
Good manners sir, teach me t'attend your bounty!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: But engine, I could wish, she would be sure
to die too night!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Alas good soul! I'll undertake
She shall do any thing to please you sir! Exit thrift.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Engine, thou hast wrought above the power
Of accident, or art!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: If you consider't with a just
And liberal brain: first, to prevent
Th'access, and tedious visits of the fiend
His lovesick monster; and then rid him hence,
Upon a journey to preserve this house
Empty, and free to celebrate the rest
Of our designs!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: This engine, is thy holiday! —Luce knocks at the chest.
What hoa! Sir Palatine, are you within?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Is sir tyrant thrift gone? open lady! open!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: The casement sir I will, a little to
Increase your witship's allowance of air! —Opens a wicket at th'end of the chest.
But th'troth, for liberty of limbs, you may
As soon expect it in a galley sir,
After six murders and a rape!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: How, lady of the lawn!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sir Lancelot,
You may believe't, if your discreet faith please;
This tenement is cheap; here you shall dwell,
Keep home, and be no wanderer!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: The pox take me if I like this! sure when
Th'advice of th'ancients is but asked, they'll say
I am now worse, than in the state of a bawd!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: D'ye know this lady sir?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: The lady ample!
Her vails off too! and in the lusty garb
Of health, and merriment! Now shall I grow
As modest as a snail that in's affliction
Shrinks up himself, and's horns into his shell,
Ashamed still to be seen.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Couldst thou believe,
Thou bearded babe! thou dull engenderer!
Male rather in the back, than in the brain,
That I could sicken for thy love? for th'cold
Society of a thin Northern wit! —Eld: Palatine sings.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Then trojans wail with great remorse,
The Greeks are locked i'th wooden horse! Enter the: palatine.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Pall, come in pall! 'tis done! the spacious man
of land, is now contented with his own length.

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.p: Your brother's come to see you sir!

sp.speaker: Elder pa.
sp.l: Brother! Mad girls these I couldst thou believe't sirrah!
I am coffined up like a salmon pie,
New sent from Den'shire for a token! Come,
Break up the chest!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Stay brother! whose chest is it?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Thou'lt ask more questions than a constable
In's sleep! prithee dispatch!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Brother, I can,
But mark the malice and the envy of
Your nature: I am no sooner exalted
To rich possessions, and a glorious mien;
But straight you tempt me to a forfeiture
Of all; to commit felony; break open chests!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: O for dame patience! the fool's mistress!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Brother, you have prayed well, heaven send her you!
You must forsake your own fair fertile soil,
To live here by your wits!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: And dream sir of
Enjoying goodly ladies six yards high!
With satin trains behind them ten yards long!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Clothed all in purple, and embroidered with
Embossments wrought in imagery, the works
O'th ancient poets drawn into similitude,
And cunning shape!

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.p: And this attained sir by your wits!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Nothing could please your haughty palate but
The Muskatelli, and Frantiniak grape!
Your Turin and your Tuscan veal, with red
Legged partridge of the Genoa hills!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: With your broad liver o'th Venetian goose;
Fattened by a Jew; and your aged carpe,
Bred i'th Geneva lake!

sp.speaker: Ampl. Luce. Ginet.
sp.p: All this maintained sir by your wits!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: And than you talked sir of your snails ta'en from
The dewy marble quarries of Carrara,
And soused in Luca oil; with cream of Switzerland,
And Genoa parcel.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Your Angelot's of Brie!
Your Marsolini, and Parmesan of Lodi!
Your Malamucka melons, and Cicilian dates!
And then to close your proud voluptuous maw,
marmalade made, by the cleanly nuns of Lisbon!

sp.speaker: Ample. Luce. Ginet.
sp.p: And still thus feasted by your wits!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Deafened with tyranny! is there no end!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Yes sir, an end of you; you shall be now
Conveyed into a close dark vault; there keep
My silent grandsire company; and all
The music of your groans, engross to your own ears!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: How! buried, and alive?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Brother! your hand! —
Farewell! I'm for the North! the fame of this
Your voluntary death, will there be thought
Pure courtesy to me; I mean to take
Possession sir, and patiently converse
With all those hinds, those herds, and flocks,
That you disdained in fullness of your wit!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Help pall to carry him! he takes it heavily! —

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: I'll not endure't! fire! murder! fire! treason!
Murder! treason! fire! —

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Alas you are not heard!
The house contains none but ourselves! Ex. carrying out the chest.

div.stage: Enter thwack, pert, meager.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: We bring you sir, commends from Palatine!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: I had as'lief, y' had brought it from the devil!
Together with his horns boiled to a jelly,
For a cordial against lust!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: We mean the younger Palatine; one sir,
That loves your person, and laments this chance,
Which his false brother hath exposed you to!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: And as we told you sir, by his command,
We have compounded with the constable;
In whose dark house, you're now a prisoner!
But sir, take't on my faith; you must disburse!
For gold is a restorative, as well
To liberty as health!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: And you believe
(It seems) that your small-tiny officer
Will take his unction in the palm as lovingly,
As your exalted grandee, that awes all
With hideous voice, and face!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Even so the Moderns render it!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: But gentlemen, you ask a hundred pounds;
'Tis all I've left!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Sir do but think what a
Prodigious blemish it will be, both to
Your ingenuity, and fame, to be
Betrayed by one, that is believed, no wittier than
Yourself, and lie imprisoned for a bawd!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Sir name it not! You kill me through the ear!
I'd rather sir, you'd take my mother from
Her grave, and put her to do penance in ▪
Her winding sheet: there is the sum! —

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: I'll in sir, and discharge you! Exit meager.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: These carnal mulcts and tributes are designed
Only to such vain people as have land;
Are you, and your friend landed sir?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Such land as we can share sir in the map!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Lo' you there now! These live by their wits!
Why should not I take the next key I meet,
And open this great head; to try, if there
Be any brains left, but sour curds, and plumbroth!
Cozened in my youth! cozened in my age!
Sir, do you judge, if I have cause to curse
This false, inhumane town! when I was young,
I was arrested for a stale commodity
Of nutcrackers, long jigs, and casting tops:
Now I am old, imprisoned for a bawd!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: These are sad tales!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: I will write down to'th country, to dehort
The gentry from coming hither, letters
Of strange dire news; you shall disperse them sir!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Most faithfully!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: That there are lents, six years long proclaimed by th'state!
That our French and deal wines are poisoned so
With brimstone by the Hollander, that they
Will only serve for medicine to recover
Children of the itch; and there is not left
Sack enough, to mull for a parson's cold!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: This needs must terrify!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: That our theatres are razed down; and where
They stood, hoarse midnight lectures preached by wives
Of comb-makers, and midwives of tower-wharf!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: 'Twill take impregnably!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: And that a new plantation sir (Mark me)
Is made i'th Coven garden, from the sutlery
O'th German campes, and the suburbs of Paris,
Where such a salt disease regnes as will make
Sassafras dearer than unicorns horn!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: This cannot choose but fright the gentry hence;
And more impoverish the town, than a
Subversion of their fair of Bartholmew,
The absence of the terms, and court!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: You shall (If my projections thrive) in less
(Sir) than a year; stable your horses in
The new exchange, and graze them in the old! —

div.stage: Enter the: Palatine, Meager, queasie, Snore, mistress: Snore.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Jog off! there's pall, treating for your liberty!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: The canopy, the hangings, and the bed,
Are worth more than your rent! come, you're overpaid!
Besides, the gentleman's betrayed! he is no bawd!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Truly, a very civil gentleman!
Alas, he hath only roared, and sworn, and cursed
Since he was ta'en: no bawdry I'll assure ye!

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Snor.
sp.p: Gossip queasy! what a goodyear would ye have?

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.p: I am content, if you and I were friends!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Come, come agree! 'tis I that ever bleed,
And suffer in your wars!

sp.speaker: Mistress Snor.
sp.l: Sweet master Palatine, hear me but speak!
Have I not often said, why neighbour queasy,
Come to my house; besides, your daughter Mall,
You know, last Pompeon time, dined with me thrice!
When my child's best yellow stockings were missing;
And a new pewter Porringer marked with P. L.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: I for Elizabeth snore!

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Snor.
sp.p: The pewterer that marked it was my uncle!

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.p: Why, did my daughter steal your goods?

sp.speaker: Mistress Snor.
sp.l: You hear me say nothing! but there is
As bad as this (I warrant ye) learned at
The backhouse! I'll have an oven o'mine own shortly!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Come, no more words! there's to reconcile you
In burnt wine, and cake! Go, get you all in!
I'm full of business, and strange mystery!

div.stage: Exeunt Snore, mistress: Snore, queasie.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: A hundred pall! 'twas all his store; it lies
Here my brave boy, warm, and secure in pouch!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: We'll share't anon. — what need your blush sir morglay,
Like a maid newly undone in a dark
Entry? There are disasters sure, as bad
As yours recorded in the city annals!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Your brother is a gentleman of a
Most even, and blessed composition, sir;
His very blood is made of holy-water,
Less salt, than almond-milk!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: My silly reprehensions were despised;
You'd be his disciple, and follow him,
In a new path, unknown to his own feet.
Yet I've walked in it since; and prospered as
You see, without or land, or tenement.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: 'Tis possible to live by'r wits! that is
As evident as light, no humane learning
Shall advise me from that faith!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Sir knight, what will you give worthy my brain,
And me; if after a concealment of
Your present shame, I can advise you, how,
T'achieve such store of wealth, and treasure, as
Shall keep you here, th'exemplar glory of
The town, a long whole year, without relief
Or charge, from your own rends. This (I take it)
Was the whole pride, at which, some few days since,
Your fancy aimed!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: This was sir in the hours
Of haughtiness and hope! but now —

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: I'll do't: whilst my poor brother too; low, and
Declined, shall see, and envy it.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Live in full port; observed, and wondered at?
Wine, ever flowing in large Saxon rumkins
About my board; with your soft sarsenet smock
At night; and foreign music to entrance?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: All this, and more than thy invention can
Invite thee too.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: I'll make thee heir of my
estate! take my right hand, and your two friends
For witnesses!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Enough! hear me with haste!
The lady ample's dead! — nay there are things
Have chanced since your concealment far more fit
For wonder sir, than this: out of a silly piety,
T'avoid a thirst of gold, and gawdy pride
I'th world; sh'ath buried with her in a chest,
Her jewels, and her clothes; besides, as I'm
Informed by Luce (My wise intelligence)
Five thousand pounds in gold; a legacy,
Left by her aunt more than her guardian knew!

sp.speaker: Thwac.
sp.p: Well, what of this?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Yourself, and I, joined sir in a most firm
And loyal league, may rob this chest!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Marry, and will!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Then when your promise is but ratified,
Take all the treasure for your own expense!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Come let us go; my fingers burn till they
Are telling it! The night will grow upon's!
Only you and I, I'll not trust new faces:
Dismiss these gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: At the next street sir!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: This is at least a grin of fortune, if
Not a fair smile. I'm still for my old problem;
Since the living rob me, I'll rob the dead!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: On my delicious Pert! Now is the time
To make our purses swell, and spirits climb! Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter the: Palatine, ample, Luce, engine, with a torch.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Engine, draw out the chest, and open the wicket!
Let us not hinder him the air, since 'tis
Become his food!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Who's there? what are you? speak!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: A brace of mourning virgin's sir; that had
You died in love, and in your wits, would now
Have brought roses, and lilies, buds of the brier,
And summer pinks to strew upon your hearse!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Then you resolve me dead!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: 'Twere good that you would so resolve yourself!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: She counsels you to wise and severe thoughts;
Why, you are no more mortified, than men
That are about to dance the morris!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Ladies, and brother too (Whom I begin
To worship now, for tenderness of heart)
Can you believe, I am so leaden, stupid,
And so very a fish, to think you dare
Thus murder me in bravery of mirth,
You have gone far: part of my sufferance I
Confess a justice to me!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O, do you so!
Hath your heart, and brain met upon that point;
And rendered you silly to your own thoughts!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Somewhat mistaken i'th projection of
My journey hither! Three hours in a chest
Among the dead; will profit more than three
Years in a study; 'mongst fathers, schoolmen,
And philosophers!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: And you're persuaded now, that there is relative
To'th maintaining of a poor younger brother,
Something beside his wits?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: 'Tis so conceived!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: And that we ladies of the town, or court,
Have not such waxen hearts, that every beam
From a hot lover's eye, can melt them through
Our breasts?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Faith, 'tis imagined too!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: That though th'unruly appetites of some
Perverted few, of our frail sex, have made
Them yield their honours to unlawful love;
Yet there is no such want of you male-sinners
As should constrain them hire you to't with gold?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: You've taught me a new music, I am all
Consent, and concordance!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: And that, the nimble packing hand, the swift
Disordered shuffle, or the slur; or his
More base employment, that with youth, and an
Eternal back, engenders for his bread;
Do all belong to men, that may be said
To live sir, by their sins, not by their wits!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Sir, whom I love not, nor desire to love,
I am of your mind too!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Madam, a fair conversion, 'tis now fit
I sue unto you, for his liberty!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Alas he hath so profited in this
Retirement, that I fear he will not willingly
Come out!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: O lady, doubt it not! Open the chest!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: A little patience sir! Enter Ginet.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: Madam, we are undone, your guardian is
At door, knocking as if he meant to wake
All his dead neighbours in the church!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.p: So soon returned! it is not midnight yet!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: I know the bait that tempts him back with such
Strange haste; and have according to your will
Provided (Madam) to betray his hopes!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.p: Excellent engine!

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.l: This key conveys you through the chancel to
The house gallery! My way lies here; I'll let
Him in, and try how our design will relish! —Exit engine.

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Come sir, it is decreed in our wise counsel,
You must be laid some distance from this place!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Pray save your labour (Madam) I'll come forth!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No sir, not yet!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.p: Brother, a cast of your voice!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: She hath the key brother! 'tis but an hour's
Dark contemplation more!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Madam, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Nay, no beginning of orations now;
This is a time of great dispatch, and haste;
We have more plots than a general in a siege! —Ex. carrying out the chest.

div.stage: Enter thrift, engine.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.l: None of the writings sir, and yet perplex
Yourself, with so much speed in a return!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: The lawyer was from home, but engine, I
Had hope to have prevented by my haste,
Though not her funeral, yet the funeral of
The chest; ah dear engine, tell me but why
So much pure innocent treasure, should be
Thus thrown into a dark forgetfulness!

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.l: I thought, I had encountered his intents!
All sir, that law, allowed her bounty to
Bestow, is yours; but for the chest; trust me,
'Tis buried sir; the key is here sir, of no use!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Ha, engine! Give it me! —

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: And sir, to vex your meditation more,
Though not with manners, yet with truth; know there
Is hidden in that chest, a plenteous heap
Of gold; together with a rope of most
Inestimable pearl, left by her late
Dead aunt by will, and kept from your discovery!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Is this true, engine?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: That precise chit luce, her cousin Puritan
Was at th'interring of't; concealed it till
The funeral forms were passed; and then forsooth,
She boasted that it was a pious means,
To avoid covetous desires i'th world ▪

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: These funeral tales (Engine) are sad indeed;
Able to melt an eye, though harder than
That heart, which did consent to so much cruelty
Upon the harmless treasure!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I mourn within sir too!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: Give me the key, that leads me from my house,
Unto the chancel door!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: 'Tis very late sir, whither will you go?

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Never too late too pray; my heart is heavy!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Where shall I wait you sir?

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: At my low gallery door, I may chance stay long.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: This takes me more than all the kindness fortune
Ever showed me: a decent transmutation.
I am no more your steward, but your spy! Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the: Palatine, Pert, meager, Snore, and watchmen.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: There, there's more money for your watch; methinks
They've not drunk wine enough; they do not chirp!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Your wine mates them, they understand it not.
But they have very good capacity in ale;
Ale sir, will heat they more than your beef brews!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Well, let them have ale then.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: O sir, 'twill make they sing like the silk-knitters
Of Cock-lane!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Meager, go you to sir tyrant thrifts house,
Luce, and the lady are alone, they will
Have cause to use your diligence, make haste!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: Your dog, tied to a bottle, shall not outrun me! Exit.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Pert, stay you here with master Constable;
and when occasion calls, see that you draw
Your lusty billmen forth; bravely advanced
Under the colours of Queen ample, and
Myself, her general!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: If ale can fortify, fear not! where's sir morglay?

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: I'm now, to meet him i'th churchyard; th'old blade
Skulks there like a tame filcher, as he had
Ne'er stolen above eggs from market women;
Robbed an orchard, or a cheese loft!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: We'll wait your worship in this corner.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: No stirring, till I either come, or send.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Pray sir let's not stay long, 'tis a cold night;
And I have nothing on my bed at home,
But a thin coverlet, and my wives say petticoat:
She'll ne'er sleep (Poor soul) till I come home
To keep here warm!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: You shall be sent for strait!
Be merry my dull sons o'th night, and chirp! Exit.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Come, neighbour runlet! sighing pays no rent,
Though the land-lady be in love! Sing out —
sp.stage: They sing a catch in four parts.
sp.l: With lantern on stall; at Trea trip we play,
For ale, cheese, and pudding, till it be day:
And for our breakfast (After long sitting)
We steal a street big, o'th constables getting.

div.stage: Enter engine.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Sir, draw down your watch into the church,
And let they lie hidden close by the vestry door!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Is he there already?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Fat carrier's sir, make not more haste to bed,
Nor lean philosophers to rise; I've so
Prepared things, that he'll find himself mistaken!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Close by the vestry door!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Right sir,
I'll to my lady, and expect th'event of your surprise!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Follow master Constable, one, and one:
All in a file! —Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter thrift, with a candle.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: I cannot find where they have laid her coffin!
But there's the chest; I'll draw it out, that I
May have more room, to search, and rifle it! —
the weight seems easy to me, though my strength
Be old; how long, thou bright all powerful mineral,
Might'st thou lie hid, ere the dull dead, that are
Entombed about thee here, could reach the sense,
To turn wise thieves, and steal thee from oblivion! —Opens it, and finds a halter.
How! A halter! what fiend affronts me with
This emblem! Is this the rope of orient pearl? —

div.stage: Enter pert, Snore, watchmen.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Now I have told you master Constable,
The entire plot; mark but, how like that chest,
Is to the other, where the elder Palatine
Lies a perdu; engine contrived them both!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Ha! what are these, the constable and watch?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Cease on him for no less than sacrilege!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Why neighbours, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: We shall know now, who stole the wainscot cover
From the font, and the vicar's surplice!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Alas grave sir, become a forfeiture
To'th King, for sacrilege!

sp.speaker: Thrif.
sp.p: Hear me but speak!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: No, not in a cause against the King!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Lead to's own house! he shall be prisoner there,
And locked up safe enough.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Undone for ever! —Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the: palate: thwack, with an iron crow, and dark lantern.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Why this was such a firk of piety,
I ne'er heard of: bury her gold with her?
'Tis strange her old shoes were not interred too;
For fear the days of Edgar should return,
When they coined leather.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: Come sir, lay down your instrument!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: I'm so taken with thy free jolly nature,
I cannot for my heart proceed to more
Defeat upon thy liberty: all that
I told thee were rank lies!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: How! no treasure trover!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Not so much as will pay for that small candle light
We waste to find it out!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: I thank you sir! —Flings down the crow of iron.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: You shall have cause, when you hear more; to this
Dark region sir, solemn, and silent, as
Your thoughts must be, ere they are mortified.
Have I now brought you, to perceive what an
Immense large ass (Under your favour knight)
You are to be seduced, to such vain stratagems
By that more profound fop, your friend, my brother!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: How had I been served, if I'd brought my scales
Hither, to weigh this gold? but on! your brother!
Whose name (Let me tell you first) sounds far worse
To me than does a sergeant to a young
Indebted lover, that's arrested in his coach,
And with his mistress by him!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: You are believed: but will you now confirm
Me to your grace and love, if I shall make't
Appear, that in a kind revenge of what
You suffered sir, I've made this false, and great
Seducer of mankind, to suffer more.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: The legend, Talmud, nor the Alcharon,
Have not such doubtful tales as these; but make't
Appear, I would have evidence!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Then take't on my religion sir, he was
Laid up in durance for a bawd before
He betrayed you to the same preferment!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Shall this be justified, when my disgrace
Comes to be known; wilt thou then witness it?

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: With a deep oath! And sir, to tempt more of
Your favours on poor me, that ever mourned
For all your sufferings; know you shall now
See him enclosed in a blind chest; where he
Lies bathed sir, in a greater sweat than ere
Cornelius took in his own tub!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Here amongst sepulchres, and melancholy bones:
Let me but see't; and I will die for joy,
To make thee instantly my heir!

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: You shall; and yet ere the sun rise, find him
Enthralled too in a new distress!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Dost want money? bring me to parchment and
A scrivener, I'll seal out two pound of wax. —Yo. Pall: knocks at the chest.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: You sir, my nearest ally, are you asleep?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.p: O brother, art thou come! quick, let me forth.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Here is a certain friend of yours presents
His loving visit sir! —Opens the wicket.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Sir morglay thwack?
I had rather have seen my sister naked!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: What, like a bashful badger do you draw
Your head into your hole again? Come sir,
Out with that sage noddle, that has contrived
So cunningly for me, and your dear self!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Here, take my eyelids knight, and sew 'em up,
I dare not see thy face!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: But what think you
Of a new journey from the North, to live
Here by your wits; or midnight visits sir,
To the mogul's niece!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: I have offended knight!
Whip me with wire, headed with rowels of
Sharp Ripon spurs! I'll endure any thing
Rather than thee!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: We have (I thank your bounteous brain)
Been entertained with various consorts sir,
Of whispering lutes, to soothe us into slumbers,
Spirits of Clare to bathe our temples in,
And then the wholesome womb of woman too,
That never teemed, all this for nothing sir!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Come, I'll let him forth!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Rogue! if thou lovest me!
Nay, let him be confined thus, one short month!
I'll send him down to country fairs for a
New motion made, b'a German engineer!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Alas, he is my brother.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Or for a solitary ape,
Lead captive thus by th' Hollander, because
He came aloft for Spain, and would not for the states!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Sir morglay leave your lantern here, and stay
My coming at yond door; I'll let him out!
But for the new distress, I promised on
His person, take it on my manhood sir,
He feels it straight!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Finely ensnared again, and instantly!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: Have a good faith, and go! Exit thwack.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Dear brother, wilt thou give me liberty!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Upon condition sir, you kiss these hilts,
Swear not to follow me, but here remain
Until the lady ample shall consent,
To'th freedom I bestow! —He kisses the hilts.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: 'Tis done! A vow inviolate! He opens the chest and lets him out.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Now silence brother! not one curse, nor thanks —

div.stage: Exit the ▪ Pall.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Fate, and a good star speed me! though I have
Long since amazed myself e'en to a marble,
Yet I have courage left, to ask, what this
Might mean? Was ever two legged man thus used! —

div.stage: Enter pert, Snore, and watchmen.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Pall, and his friend are gone, I must not stay
His sight; but after you have ceased upon him
Lead him a prisoner to the lady too. —Exit Pert.

sp.speaker: Sno.
sp.p: Warrant ye, though he were gog, or Heldebrand! —They lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal:
sp.p: How now? What mean you sirs?

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.p: Yield to the constable.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: 'Tis yielded sir, that you are constable!
But where have I offended!

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: Here sir, you have committed sacrilege,
And robbed an alderman's tomb, of himself,
And his two sons kneeling in brass!

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.p: How, flay monuments of their brazen skins?

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: Look, a dark lantern, and an iron crow!
Fine evidence for a jury! —

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: I like this plot! The lady ample and
My brother, have most rare, triumphant wits;
Now by this hand, I am most eagerly
In love with both; I find I have deserved all;
And am resolved t'hug them, and their designs;
Though they afflict me more, and more! Whither must I go?

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: Away with him! Saucy fellow! examine
The King's constable ▪ —Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter young palatine, thwack, ample, Luce, Meager.

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.l: I am become your guardians jailor, lady;
He's safe locked in the parlour, and there howls
Like a dog that sees a witch flying!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: I long to hear how my wise tutor thrives
I'th new defeat!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: 'Tis well you are converted!
Believe't that gentleman deserves your thanks.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Lady seal my conversion on you Lipp;
'Tis the first leading kiss, that I intend
For after chastity! —Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Luce, see you make the proposition good
which I shall give my brother from this lady,
Or I'll so swaddle your small bones.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sweet pall, thou shalt. Madam, you'll please to stand
To what I lately mentioned to your own desire?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: To every particle, and more. —Enter Pert.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Your brother's come; this room must be his prison.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: 'Way luce, away: stand in the closet madam,
That you may hear us both, and reach my call.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: I'll stay, and see him.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: No knight; you are decreed sir Tyrant's judge:
Go that way sir, and force him to compound.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: I'll fine him soundly,
Till's purse shrink like a bladder in the fire ▪ —Ex. Amp. Luc. Thw. Meag. Pert.

div.stage: Enter Snore, elder Palatine.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Here sir, this is your jail, too good for such
A great offender.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Sacrilege! very well.
Now all the pulpit cushions, all the hearse clothes,
And winding sheets, that have been stolen about
The town this year, will be laid to my charge!

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Pray leave us master Constable, and look
Unto your other bondman in the parlour. —Exit Snore.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: This is the wittiest offspring that our name
Ere had: I love him beyond hope, or lust,
My father was no poet sure, I wonder
How he got him?

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: I know you curse me now.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.p: Brother, introth you lie, and who ere believes it.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Indeed you do: conjurers in a circle,
That have raised up a wrong spirit, curse not
So much, nor yet so inwardly.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.p: I've a great mind to kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.p: You have not sure?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: I shall do't, and eat up thy lips so far,
Till thou'st nothing left to cover thy teeth.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: And can you think all the afflictions you
Endured, were merited; first, for misleading
Morglay, your old friend; then, neglect of me,
And haughty overvaluing yourself?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Brother, I murmur not; the traps that you
Have laid, were so ingenious, I could wish
To fall in them again.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: The lady ample sir,
There is the great contriver that hath weaved
these knots so intricate and safe: alas, I
Was but her lowly instrument.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Ah that lady! were I a King, she should
Sit with me under my best canopy,
A silver sceptre in her hand; with which,
I'd give her leave to break my head for every fault
I did commit.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: But say, I bring this lady sir, unto
Your lawful sheets; make her your bosom wife:
Besides, the plenty of her heritage,
How would it sound, that you had conquered her
Who hath so often conquered you?

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Dear brother, no new plots.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Six thousand pounds sir is your yearly rent;
A fair temptation to a discreet lady:
Luce, hath filled both mine ears with hope; besides,
I heard her say, she ne'er should meet a man,
That she could more subdue with wit, and government.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: That I'll venture.

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: Well, my first bounty is your freedom sir;
For'th constable obeys no law, but mine.
And now, madam! Appear! —Enter ample, Luce.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: You're welcome 'mongst the living sir?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: Lady, no words; if you've but so much mercy
As could secure one that your eyes affect.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Why, you're grown arrogant again: d'ye think
They are so weak, to affect you?

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: I have a heart so kind unto myself,
To wish they could; oh we should live.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Not by our wits.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: No, no! but with such soft content; still in
Conspiracy, how to betray ourselves
To new delights, keep harmony, with no
More noise, than what the upper motions make;
And this so constant too, turtles themselves,
Seeing our faith, shall slight their own, and pine
With jealousy.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Luce, the youth talks sense now, no medicine for
The brain, like to captivity in a dark chest.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: O madam, you are cruel!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Well my sad convertite: joy yet at this:
I've often made a vow, to marry on
That very day my wardship is expired:
and two hours since, that liberty begun.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Nay, hear her out! your wishes are so saucy sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: And know, my glory is dispatch. My ancestors
Were of the fiery French, and taught me love,
Hot eagerness, and haste!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Let me be rude
A while; lie with your judgement, and beget
Sages on that! My dearest, chiefest lady! —

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Your brain's yet foul, and will recoil again.

sp.speaker: Elder ▪ Pall.
sp.p: No more: I'll swallow down my tongue!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: If sir, your nature be so excellent,
As your kind brother hath confirmed to Luce.
And me; follow, and I'll present you straight
With certain writings you shall seal to, hoodwinked,
And purely ignorant of what they are?
This is the swiftest, and the easiest test,
That I can make of your bold love; do this,
Perhaps, I may vouchsafe to marry you ▪
The writings are within.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: Lead me to trial, come!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: But sir, if I should marry you; it is
In confidence, I have the better wit;
And can subdue you still to quietness,
Meek sufferings, and patient awe.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.p: You rap me still anew.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: In Luce, our hopes grow strong, and giantly! Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter thrift, Snore, mistress: Snore, queasie, Ginet.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: To him mistress snore; 'tis he has kept
Your husband from his bed so long, to watch
Him for a church robbery!

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Snor.
sp.l: Ah, thou Judas! I thought what thou'dst come to!
Remember the warrant thou sentest for me
Into Duck-lane, 'cause I called thy maid Trot!
When I was fain t'invite thy clerk to a
Fee pie, sent me b'a temple cook, my sister's sweetheart!

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.l: Nay, and remember who was brought to bed
Under thy coach house wall; when thou devidest
A wad of straw, and wouldst not join thy halfpenny
To send for milk, for the poor chrisom!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Now you may sweeten me with sugarloafs
At new-year-tide, as I have you sir. —

div.stage: Enter thwack, pert, meager, engine.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: We'll teach you to rob churches! 'slight, hereafter
We of the pious shall be afraid to go
To a long exercise, for fear our pockets should
Be picked! Come sir, you see already how
The neighbours throng to find you; will you consent?
'Tis but a thousand pounds a piece to these
Two gentlemen; and five hundred more to engine.
Your crime is then concealed, and yourself free.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: No, he may choose, he'll trust to'th kind hearted law.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Let him, and to dame justice too, who though
Her ladyship be blind, will grope hard sir,
To find your money bags.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Sir you are rich ▪ besides, you know what you
Have got by your wards death; I fear you will
Be begged at court, unless you come off thus.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: There is my closet key, do what you please.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'll lead you to it, follow me.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: D'ye use to find such sums as these beneath
An oak, after a long march; I think sure,
The wars are not so plentiful.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: We think so too.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Y'had better trail a bodkin, gentlemen,
Under the lady ample, than a pike
Under a German general.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: We'll in for th'mony sir, and talk anon. Ex. Eng. Per. Meag.

div.stage: Enter eld: Palatine, the: Palatine, ample, Luce.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: Sir tyrant thrift, here is your ward come from
The dead, t'indite you for a robbery
Upon her ghost.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Ha! Is she alive too?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, and her wardship out, before you've proffered her
A husband sir; so the best benefit
Of all your guardianship is lost.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: In seven long years you could not sir provide
A man deformed enough, to offer me
For your own ends.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Cozened of wealth, of fame! Dog engine! Ex. thrift.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: We must have you enclosed again: you're very
Forward with the lady.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: I will be sir,
Until she groan! this priest stays some what long.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: How's this? troth I shall forgive thee then heartily.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I've ta'en him i'th behalf of health; to chide
And jeer, for recreation's sake, 'twill keep
Me sir, in breath, now I am past growing.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Hark knight! here's relish for your ears. I chose
None of your dull country madams, that spend
Their time in studying receipts, to make
Marchpane, and preserve plums; that talk
Of painful childbirths, servants wages, and
Their husbands good complexion, and his leg!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: New wonders yet!

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: What was that (Mistress) which I sealed to, hoodwinked?
A simple trial of my confidence and love.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Your brother has it, 'tis a gift to him
Of one fair manor, 'mongst those many that you
Have in possession sir; and in this bond,
You're witness to three thousand pounds I give to luce!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes sir, for pall and I must marry too.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: I were an eunuch else, and th'world should know't.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: Thou couldst not have betrayed me to a bounty
I more love. Brother! Give thee joy! —Thw. takes the: Pall. aside.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: You are the cause of all these miracles:
Therefore I desire you to be my heir;
By this good day you must: for I've taken order,
Though I love your wit, you shall not live by it.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.p: My kind thanks sir, the poor man's gratitude.

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Snor.
sp.l: 'Give you joy sweet master palatine, and
Your brother too.

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.l: And send you more such wives,
Every year as many as shall please heaven.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: 'Tis day. I'll not to bed sir now; my watch
Shall be drunk, at your worship's wedding.

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: They shall, and there is gold enough to keep
Them so, until thy reign be out. —

div.stage: Enter pert, meager, engine, with money bags.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Loaden with composition pall. —

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: 'Tis for your sake we groan under these burdens. —

sp.speaker: Young Pall.
sp.l: The offal of sir Tyrant's trunks! Brother,
Pray know these gentlemen, they owe you more
Money than they mean to pay now.

sp.speaker: Elder Pal.
sp.l: I remember they: but no words my cavaliers,
And you are safe. Where shall we dine today?

sp.speaker: Young Pal.
sp.l: At Lucy's ants; we'll make her costive beldamship
Come off; when she beholds a goodly jointure,
And our fair hopes.

sp.speaker: Elder Pall.
sp.l: First, to the church. Lady,
I'll make your skittish person sure. Some of
Your pleasant arts upon me, may become
A wise example, and a moral too;
Such as their haughty fancy well befits,
That undertake to live here by their wits. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: The office of an epilogue, is now
To smooth and ▪ stroke the wrinkles from each brow;
To guide severer judgements (If we could
Be wise enough) until they thought all good,
Which they perhaps dislike; and sure, this were
An overboldness, raised from too much fear.
You have a freedom, which we hope you'll use,
To advance our youthful poet, and his muse
With a kind doom; and he'll tread boldly then
In's best new comic socks, this stage again.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
